Mr. Speaker, I rise on a question of privilege.
The news last night and this morning indicated that the hon. member for Lotbiniere has been convicted of misuse of funds of the House of Commons. Members of the House obviously have refrained from making any comments until the final resolution had taken place.
We have learned of the conviction and now the House must decide. Normally the member would have resigned and maybe that has already taken place. Perhaps I could seek some information from the government side.
It is the tradition of this House always to discipline its members in addition to the discipline meted out by the
courts.
Mr. Speaker, I would ask that you give some guidance regarding the consideration of taking action on this case. If there is a particular course of action to be taken I would be prepared of course to move the appropriate motion.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member for Kamloops and I have roughly an equivalent formation in the law and he would know as I do that this is a matter which may still be before the courts.
He made reference to the wisdom of the House in letting court processes be carried through to their conclusion. It would seem to me, Mr. Speaker, for your
guidance, that was a prudent course at the time. In the circumstances, it remains a prudent course.
It would be well for all of us to respect the difference between the political functions that occur here which always require some restraint and the functions of the courts.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my colleague and friend from the New Democratic Party has made an intervention. I wish the record to show that in the adjudication announced by the courts the sentencing will not take place until the new year.
There may be appeals. There could be questions of law which would thereafter be examined in a higher court. Mr. Speaker, I am not attempting to advise you on all the aspects of law, but I do not believe at this time it would be the most appropriate thing to do in view of what the courts have before them.
I would suggest that you give careful consideration to the interventions made by the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs and me.

Mr. Speaker, I want to make it clear to my hon. friends this was not intended to mean that we should act in haste.
This was the first opportunity we have had since learning the news. I felt that we should at least seek some clarification as to what the course may be.
Having heard these interventions in terms of the recognition of the right of appeal, we await some advice from you, Mr. Speaker.

The hon. member for Kamloops has raised a matter which of course is of importance to this House. The right hon. minister has responded on the government side and the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond on behalf of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition.
The matter raised is the announcement of the conviction of a member of Parliament for certain offences.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
There is a convention which I expect would be followed. It is that the court will inform the Chair officially of what has transpired. I do not anticipate receiving that this morning or maybe not even for some days.
The other matter referred to is the question of an appeal. I am not in a position, nor I suppose are hon. colleagues, to know whether an appeal would be taken. I think we should look carefully at that.
Again, we do not know what is likely to transpire at the sentencing or what arguments may be used by the defence at that time, all of which would affect whatever action this place might ultimately take.
We had a matter like this some years ago. Hon. members will remember that I took the matter under advisement to consider my position and to consider what was appropriate under the circumstances. As it turned out, the matter was resolved without the necessity of the Chair having to make any ruling at all.
However, the hon. member for Kamloops has, as he said, brought this matter to the attention of the House at the first possible opportunity. If I understood him correctly, he is not suggesting that the House should take any sudden action today, but when it is appropriate under all the circumstances.
I will take the application of the hon. member under advisement. As soon as I am in a position to advise the House further I shall do so.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration) moved:

speechtext:
1.	The Constitution Act, 1982 is amended by adding thereto, immediately after section 16 thereof, the following section:
"16.1 (1) The English linguistic community and the French linguistic community in New Brunswick have equality of status and equal rights and privileges, including the right to distinct educational institutions and such distinct cultural institutions as are necessary for the preservation and promotion of those communities.
(2) The role of the legislature and government of New Brunswick to preserve and promote the status, rights and privileges referred to in subsection (1) is affirmed."
2.	This amendment may be cited as the Constitution Amendment, year of proclamation (New Brunswick).
He said: Madame Speaker, in the parliamentary life of any politician, there are moments that have special significance and remain engraved on our hearts for a long time. Today is one of those moments.
From the time of our earliest forebears and during the relentless efforts of past generations to carve out a place in this difficult landscape, to create a safe home for their language and culture, our country-which is more than a mere territory-has been a crucible in which was forged a historic reconciliation of two languages and cultures.

We are witnesses today to the culmination of a long historical development which is also the beginning of a new journey for the English and French linguistic communities of New Brunswick and indeed of Canada. Today is one of those history-making moments for New Brunswick's two official language communities.
The constitutional resolution we are proposing to pass today will entrench in Canada's Constitution the main provisions of an act recognizing the two official linguistic communities in New Brunswick.
This constitutional amendment recognizes the principle of equal status, equal rights and equal privileges for these two language communities. In particular, it recognizes the right to the separate educational and cultural institutions that are necessary for their protection and promotion.
December 11, 1992

It also reaffirms the role of New Brunswick's legislature and government to protect and promote the status, rights and privileges of these language communities.
The constitutional amendment proposed by the New Brunswick legislative assembly is the fruit of a number of years of constant effort by governments and the people of this province.

It is the direct consequence of the enactment of the act recognizing the two official linguistic communities in New Brunswick, better know as Bill 88 or the Equality Act, which was passed under the Hatfield government in July 1981.
Bill 88 is much more than a mere legal provision. For New Brunswick's Acadian community, Bill 88 was intended to respond to the legitimate aspirations of Acadian men and women as expressed at the Convention d'orientation nationale des Acadiens, held in 1979 in Edmundston, the principal town in my riding.
I participated in that convention, and the spirit that inspired it bore witness to the courage and determination to equip the Acadian community with the tools it needed for its cultural, linguistic and economic development. Important steps had already been taken at that time.
Former Premier Robichaud, now a senator, had embarked on major reforms, particularly the Official Languages Act and the equal opportunities for all programs. Under the leadership of his successor, Premier Hatfield, and his minister, Jean Maurice Simard, also a senator now, several further reforms were implemented, such as duality in the Department of Education, community centres, schools and so forth.

In the same vein as its predecessors who were the pioneers. Premier McKenna's government supported these reforms and committed itself, with the leaders of the Progressive Conservative and the New Democratic opposition parties to entrenching this recognition of equality in the Canadian Constitution. This was at-
Govemment Orders
tempted in amendments to the Meech Lake accord of June 9, 1990 and in the Charlottetown agreement.
It should be made clear that at no time during this period and these negotiations did the province of New Brunswick, the provincial governments or the federal government waiver from the purpose of entrenching these principles.

I wish to refer especially to the efforts and indefatigable support of the Prime Minister, without whom passage of the resolution today would be far from certain. All official language minorities can count on the Prime Minister as a staunch friend, and I want to thank him personnaly on behalf of all New Brunswickers for his constant support and leadership on this issue.

For New Brunswick's anglophone community Bill 88 and the entrenchment of its main provisions in Canada's Constitution means a number of things.
First, it confirms almost inalienably the road that the two communities have taken together for many years now, the progress they have made together and the future they want to build together as partners, not opponents.
It testifies to an irreversible social maturity that wants to develop a common existence and pass on to future generations of New Brunswickers their desire to continue this social and economic experiment.
This resolution enables anglophone communities which are in a minority situation in some areas to take control of their own cultural and linguistic development in the field of education and other government services.
In a community like Madawaska-Victoria, my riding, the main town, Edmonston, a small community of 12,000 people, has a population of only 4 per cent of anglophones. Because of the spirit in New Brunswick and because of that duality, these people have separate school boards in my home town, district 33. Therefore, this constitutional measure testifies to New Brunswick's generous and creative vision of Canada's future.
Government Orders

This province is a microcosm of the Canadian federal reality. On our home ground, by working devotedly, making compromises and above all respecting the reality of others, we have succeeded in creating a climate of understanding that is conducive to fruitful and satisfactory linguistic arrangements.
As you know, the constitutional amendment we are debating today had a proper place in the Charlottetown agreement. When the referendum was held, more than 60 per cent of my compatriots voted in favour of the constitutional agreement laid before them.
In other words, not only did they support the constitutional amendment that particularly affected them, but they were still sufficiently generous to accept the other compromises that would have put us on the road to greater national solidarity and consequently greater prosperity.
However that may be, the possibility of such a bilateral constitutional resolution is provided for in section 43 of the Constitution Act, 1982.

New Brunswick has always been a haven for our two linguistic communities. Many Acadian men and women found refuge there after the deportation in 1755. It was there that the Loyalists, fleeing the United States, established a home following the Treaty of Paris in 1783.
Today this tradition of hospitality to strangers is still very strong among us. New citizens come from all over the world with the goal of building here, with us, a bright future for themselves and their descendants.

This constitutional amendment will strengthen this social fabric and give it a permanent foundation. It is also a splendid and significant step forward for the men and women in New Brunswick involved in a continuing search for harmony based on self-confidence and openness to others.

I fervently hope that this example of respect for differences, of tolerance toward cultural diversity and of receptiveness to others spreads throughout Canada. Despite the difficulties that have sometimes marred the
development of our national identity, the truth is that we have more things in common to celebrate than we have differences to define.

A historic moment such as we are experiencing today, at the beginning of this holiday season when we celebrate men and women of good will, can only strengthen us in our sincere desire to extend the productive lessons of New Brunswick's experience to Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
subsubtopic: AMENDMENT TO THE CONSTITUTION OF CANADA
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am very proud to get up today in this House to support the motion. It is not every day that I agree with the Minister of Employment and Immigration, but I am delighted to get up today to support his motion.

As you all know, becoming the member for Beausejour was probably one of the finest moments of my political career.

To get up today and to speak on this motion gives me great pleasure. The minister referred to an historic moment and it is, indeed, a big one.
It is Canada at its best. This is the generosity, the tolerance, the diversity that has made this country what it is. This is what we are enshrining in the Constitution for New Brunswick.

Going around that riding in the past two years, I realized that a third of my constituents were Englishspeaking and two-thirds were French-speaking. They all live together, but they have their own schools. They share a common life but are separate at the same time.

When you are in Sackville, Dorchester, Cape Tormen-tine, Port Elgin, you have people who came from the United States to Canada. They were Loyalists who wanted to remain part of what they believed in. In those days it was the British Empire. They did not want to join the American revolution.
December 11, 1992



Then you go to the other side, to Cap-Pele, Shediac, Buctouche and you see these French speaking people, these Acadians, who were deported and came back, but who kept the French language and culture in absolutely incredible conditions. They are proud of their Frenchness, they are proud of speaking French and very proud of being New Brunswickers; nothing will stop them from remaining French speaking. They are very proud to be Canadian.
If that spirit prevailed in the country from coast to coast, I think it would be the best example that Canada could give to the whole world. When we see the problems in the world today, where people kill one another because of cultural or language differences and you go to New Brunswick or to my riding, the smallest English speaking communities have their school commission, the French speaking community has its school commissions and they live and work together for the economic progress of that community; this is Canada at its best.
Today, as I speak in this House as the member for Beausejour, I am pleased to support this motion, because in the history of New Brunswick and especially of the French community in New Brunswick, they have taken their destiny in hand, with this unfailing perseverance and determination.
The minister talked about Senator Robichaud, who decided to shake New Brunswick's cage, so to speak, by proposing to make the two language communities equal. Later Richard Hatfield took up the torch and today Premier Frank McKenna is continuing to advance the cause.

For me it is a great day. It is an example that we can be together and at the same time be different in Canada. I have my colleagues with me. The member for Moncton and the other members live that by the day. They are all elected, every one of them, by francophones and anglophones. They manage to keep them happy.
That is the way I would like this country to work. It is not the Charlottetown accord or anything else. This is a commitment of these two communities that was done a long time ago. When we amended the Constitution in 1982, we made provisions so that some amendments could be made to the Constitution in a bilateral way between the provincial and the federal governments.
Government Orders
That is exactly why it is there. There are some elements in the Constitution that affect only one province. It will not be unique to New Brunswick. For example, in Newfoundland they have the duality of the school system based on religion. This does not exist in other provinces. The same thing exists in Quebec. It is not the case in Ontario and other provinces. We need to have that flexibility in the Constitution. It is being used for a very noble purpose today.
In conclusion, I would like to say that it is a great example of understanding, generosity, tolerance and diversity.

Since I will unfortunately not be a candidate in the riding of Beausejour at the next election, I am happy to take the opportunity given me today to support the government's proposal and ensure that the Canadian Constitution will fully protect New Brunswick's French speaking community. This is a great day. I am pleased to support this motion and I take the opportunity to thank the people of Beausejour who have been so generous to me and my wife these last two years during which I represented them.

All these places, Cape Tormentine, Sackville, Dorchester, Memramcook up to Richibucto, are the best of Canada.
Therefore, it is with great pleasure that I support this motion.
I move, seconded by the hon. member for Acadie-Bathurst:
That the question be now put.

speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: AMENDMENT TO THE CONSTITUTION OF CANADA
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I too wish to say a few words on behalf of my party in support of the motion before the House today to amend the Constitution of Canada.
It is really a very rare day indeed in this country when we actually amend the Constitution of Canada. We have spent many hours and many years talking about constitutional reform, but today we are actually amending the Constitution and making this country a better place not just for the people in New Brunswick, but a better place for all of us regardless of where we live.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
I am very proud, on behalf of my party, to say that we support the amendment of the Constitution to enshrine in our constitutional law the equality of the linguistic communities of the anglophones and francophones in the province of New Brunswick.
I do that for two reasons. First of all, the process here is the right process and, second, because of the substance of what we are doing today in terms of New Brunswick. In terms of process, this amendment has come through a long and very open process in the province of New Brunswick.
I can remember years ago speaking with New Brunswick people about the process in that province toward the fight for linguistic equality of the two communities. Away back in July 1981 the New Brunswick legislature passed a law guaranteeing the equality of the two official language communities in that province. In 1982, in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, we had section 16 that guarantees the equality of the French and English languages in the province of New Brunswick, making it the only officially bilingual province in this country.
We can go on to 1989 and 1992 when two legislative committees in New Brunswick recommended further constitutional change after extensive public hearings in the province of New Brunswick.

This process has been going on for many years. Right here in this House, the language situation in the province of New Brunswick has already been studied.
I very well remember Mr. McKenna two years ago during the Meech Lake crisis. We also had a committee, chaired by the Minister of the Environment and the same proposal was in the Charest report. In June 1990, we also had a resolution in this House to change the Canadian Constitution for New Brunswick. The motion was already before the House then, but unfortunately it was not presented to the members.
I also remember the Beaudoin-Dobbie report very well. It was supported by every political party in Canada. We also supported the proposal on New Brunswick in the Beaudoin-Dobbie report. Later, we had the Charlottetown accord. Despite the result of the referendum on that accord, the Charlottetown proposal received very strong support in New Brunswick, both from anglophones and from francophones. If I remember correctly, over 60 per cent of the people in New Brunswick supported the Charlottetown agreement. Again, the New Brunswick proposal was included in this agreement, Madam Speaker. It was supported by the people, by the provincial government members and by the members from the three major parties represented in this House.
On Friday, December 4, the resolution was introduced and adopted by the New Brunswick Legislative Assembly in Fredericton. It was supported by the McKenna Liberal Party, by the Conservative Party as well as by the hon. member and leader of the other party at the Legislative Assembly, Elizabeth Weir.
I would like to say a few words about Mr. Hatfield. He was the premier of that province for many years and he fought hard for linguistic equality in New Brunswick. He has accomplished many positive things for the Acadians as well as for the other people of the province.
I can also remember another former premier, Mr. Robichaud, a Liberal premier, who has done exactly the same thing for New Brunswick. The other party has always been quite small in that province, but nonetheless present, as exemplified by Elizabeth Weir last week, at the Legislative Assembly.

For all kinds of reasons of process what we are doing today is the right thing. This has been studied by people in New Brunswick, by committees in that province and by federal committees for the last number of years. It has been before the House previously. It was part of the companion resolution of Mr. McKenna back in 1990. It was part of the Charest report and part of the Beaudoin-Dobbie report. It was supported by all political parties as the right and proper thing to do.
Last Friday the legislature passed it, supported by the three national parties in the province of New Brunswick. They have now asked the federal Parliament, the Senate and the House of Commons, to pass the resolution as
December 11, 1992

required under section 43 of our Constitution Act to make this an amendment to the Constitution of Canada.
The process has been open, consultative and supported by the people and the legislature of the province of New Brunswick. Of course the resolution applies only to the province of New Brunswick.
The second point I would like to make on why we should be supporting this today is its substance. It is right and just to make sure we have equality between the two linguistic communities in that province. It is an act of generosity, an act of tolerance, an act that reflects our history that we have in this country as a whole two linguistic communities.
New Brunswick is really a microcosm of Canada. One-third of New Brunswickers are francophones and about two-thirds are anglophones. In order for the community to survive and thrive, the equality of those two communities should be enshrined in our Constitution. Our party has always supported minority language rights, openness, generosity and tolerance when it comes to the two languages in this country. I am very proud to be supporting this amendment to the Constitution of Canada on behalf of our party.
I want to conclude by briefly making a couple of more points. The first is that we are doing this in the proper way. In 1981 we had about four or five ways agreed upon at that time on how to amend our Constitution. One way was through unanimous consent for about five different items. The major way was with the support of two-thirds of the provinces, with 50 per cent of the population residing in the province and with the support of Parliament. That was the bulk of the amendments to our Constitution. That was the bulk of Charlottetown.
The third way was a bilateral way where the amendment affects one or more provinces but not all provinces. It had to be passed by the legislatures of those provinces and by the Parliament of Canada, under section 43 of the Constitution of Canada. It is interesting that section 43(b) also refers directly to language issues. It states: "Any amendment to any provision that relates to the use of the English or French language within a province".
What we are doing here is precisely what is called for in terms of the Constitution of Canada as patriated by then Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.
Government Orders
That leads me to my last two points. There is a concern by some people that maybe what we are doing here is introducing something new called collective rights. I just want to say that line of thinking is absolutely wrong. We already have in our Constitution many times references to collective rights of people, linguistic rights in terms of the French language and English language all across this country. We have in section 16 of the Constitution the listing of those rights. We also have in section 23 guarantees for official language minorities. Be they English in Quebec for education or the francophones outside Quebec for education, those are collective rights. They are already in the Constitution of Canada.
In addition to linguistic rights and educational rights, we have rights for the aboriginal people that are already part of the Constitution of this country. In addition to that we have rights in Canada for people who come from many different multicultural and multiracial backgrounds. I suppose we could even say that under section 36 we have certain economic obligations of the federal government to provide equalization and regional development plans to help poor provinces, and again that helps collectivities in the poorer parts of the country.
Any challenge to what we are doing today is a very shallow challenge. It reflects people who go back to the 19th century and think the only rights that are important are individual rights. That is a very reactionary thing of the past and something we should be turning down as Canadians. This is a very positive, progressive amendment to the Constitution. It is in sync with what we have done before. It is an extension of what we have done before.
The last point I want to make before I sit down is that I do sometimes worry about the future of this country. I want to say at this time I know that the minister himself worries about the future of this country. The Minister Responsible for the Constitutional Affairs has done many months of very fine work in trying to build a national consensus. It is not just the minister; indeed many people in this House and many of the provincial political leaders across the country have worked hard. That consensus did not achieve fruition. We saw the results of the October 26 referendum.

Government Orders
Despite that, despite the fact that I sometimes worry about the future of this country, I think that within Canada and all regions of this country there is a great feeling that we must keep this country together. There is a great feeling that we must find ways of reforming our institutions, making this institution more meaningful, binding our country together and expressing that tolerance and that generosity to keep the country together as we move on to the 21st century.
I am optimistic about the future of Canada. I think this country is going to work. The gesture of today is a very concrete step in making this country better not only for the Acadian minority, not only for New Brunswick, but for all Canadians regardless of where we may live.

subsubtopic: AMENDMENT TO THE CONSTITUTION OF CANADA
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is with great emotion and pride that I participate in this historic debate on a motion authorizing an amendment to the Constitution Act of 1982 in order to enshrine: (1) that the English linguistic community and the French linguistic community in New Brunswick have equality of status and equal rights and privileges, including the right to distinct educational institutions and such distinct cultural institutions as are necessary for the preservation and promotion fo those communities; (2) that the role of the legislature and government of New Brunswick to preserve and promote the status, rights and privileges referred to above is affirmed.
The two official language communities of New Brunswick have shown great understanding and generosity, and it is this spirit of liberality and magnanimity that allows us today to enshrine in our Constitution this principle of equality which is so important for our people's harmonious development.
For the Acadian community in my province, the recognition of these rights is the result of a very long struggle. A century ago, the Acadian people gave themselves a few emblems to rally around such as a flag, an
anthem and a national day. From these symbolic actions emerged a defensive nationalism, whose first priority is to preserve their language, culture and religion. Eventually they established ways to develop their economy, such as the Acadian co-operative movement, to ensure that the survivors of Grand-Pre would continue to survive.
Rapid progress was made when Louis Robichaud was elected as the first Acadian premier of New Brunswick in 1960. The University of Moncton was founded in 1963 and the Official Languages Act was proclaimed in 1969.
The equal opportunities program launched by Mr. Robichaud in the sixties has been essential to Acadians achieving recognition of the equal status they now enjoy with their English speaking neighbours.
Two figures who followed in the footsteps of Mr. Robichaud also deserve our recognition and gratitude, and I am referring to the late Richard Hatfield, who became premier in 1970, and the present premier, the Hon. Frank McKenna, who on Friday, December 4, led the legislature of my province in passing a resolution that recognizes the equal status of both official language communities of New Brunswick.
I want to thank my colleagues in the New Brunswick legislature whose co-operation made it possible for us to take part in this important event in Acadian history and in the history of New Brunswick and Canada. The support shown for Premier McKenna's resolution by the leader of the Conservative Party of New Brunswick, Dennis Cochrane, and by the members of his caucus, and the support of the leader of the New Democratic Party, Ms. Elizabeth Weir, is tangible proof that friendship and understanding between two official language communities are possible in this country.
I want to thank the Government of Canada, led by Prime Minister and seconded by the hon. member for Madawaska-Victoria and Minister of Employment and Immigration for what they did today.
It is a great privilege to witness this historic day with the Leader of the Opposition who sponsored the enshrinement in the Constitution of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and who represents a large number of Acadians as the member for Beausejour in my province. A coincidence, I would say, that proves that luck is always on the side of those who persevere.
December 11, 1992

On this day, as we witness the end of a long struggle for harmony and the enhancement of both official language communities of New Brunswick, it is also appropriate to mention the many people who worked so hard, often without public recognition, that we might experience this historic moment.
I am thinking of Father Clement Cormier, Martin Legere, Raymond Gionet, Dr. Marcel Sormany, Dr. Alexandre Savoie, Antonine Maillet, Hedard Robi-chaud, Blanche Bourgeois, the nuns who worked with such dedication in Acadia, Gilbert Finn, Marie-Esther Robichaud, Michel Doucet, Michel Bastarache and many others who worked without respite for equal status for New Brunswick's Acadians.
Madam Speaker, need I add that these pioneers and passionate defenders of the cause acted in the best Acadian tradition by avoiding confrontation and fruitless debate, preferring instead the route of dialogue and compromise.

The English speaking majority in New Brunswick is made up of Canadians whose origins can be traced to many lands: Ireland, Scotland, India, England, Germany, Italy, Pakistan, the United States. The list is very long.
1 want to say today to my colleagues in this place that what makes so many of them so very special is that they share a tradition of generosity of spirit and a commitment to fairness and equity that makes me extremely proud to be a New Brunswicker.

This day will remain engraved forever in the collective memory of Acadians as the conclusion of one of the longest battles ever fought by a Canadian minority, determined to contribute in a positive way to the development of its province and its country.
This is a solemn moment, and all those who helped write this chapter in our history deserve our admiration, gratitude and respect. In concluding, I want to say this is a great day for Acadia, and I hope that the example set by New Brunswick's two official language minorities will be followed by others across Canada.
Christmas has come early this year for Acadians, and speaking on behalf of my colleagues-the hon. member for Restigouche-Chaleur, the hon. member for Monc-
Govemment Orders
ton, the hon. member for Miramichi-and all New Brunswickers, I can assure you we are very grateful.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, first of all, I would like to point out the big effort of the members from New Brunswick in this House who agreed to table and sponsor this motion today. As members of the Bloc Quebecois, we are extremely pleased to endorse this motion. However, I would like to make some comments.
We did not have a chance to examine it more closely and I wonder whether the Meech Lake accord would pass as quickly if it came back to the House today. The Meech Lake accord let Quebec return to the Canadian Constitution upright and not on its knees. I wonder if the other Canadian provinces would have the courage New Brunswick has in recognizing duality and the founding peoples. I take Ontario for example. It is making slow progress, but should follow New Brunswick's example. Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and the other provinces should imitate Quebec, for all purposes. But no, that was not done. Furthermore, it was confirmed in the massive rejection of the Charlottetown accord throughout Canada. Not only Quebec voted against the Charlottetown accord, but many other provinces of Canada, like British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Nova Scotia; the Toronto region voted yes, but when the outlying regions are included, 50 per cent of Ontarians voted against the Charlottetown accord.
We will support this motion because the Bloc Quebecois would not want to prevent Canada from developing as Canadians want. At the same time, we are showing this House again today that Quebec is being prevented from developing as it wants.
Just a few weeks ago, when the House returned, the minister who tabled this motion, supported by the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, told us, in answer to a request from the Bloc Quebecois to transfer occupational training to Quebec, that the Government of Quebec's requests could not be granted because the people had voted against the Charlottetown accord. Today these same ministers are tabling this motion and asking the House to agree to pass it on first, second and third reading in the same day, which we will do.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
In conclusion, I say that this country, Canada, divided as it might be, is never divided because of Quebec. We in Quebec want the rest of Canada to develop as Canadians want, as long as they let Quebec develop as the people of Quebec want and agree to that.

Madam Speaker, yesterday was Human Rights Day and I was therefore pleased that the Minister of Justice tabled legislation to amend the Human Rights Act and that this discussion is now in the public domain.
I was most disappointed, however, that the legislation failed to explicitly define what constituted a family relationship. I am also disappointed that it did not state categorically that spousal benefits were exclusively available to heterosexual families.
I am also troubled that the legislation merely added sexual discrimination to the long list of personal attributes which we do not discriminate against rather than state quite plainly that we do not discriminate against people based on their personal attributes, whatever those attributes may be.
In short, the legislation lacks definition where it needs it and it has too much definition where it does not. I call upon the Minister of Justice to review these amendments to ensure that they do two things. First, they effectively protect all Canadians from discrimination and, second, they strengthen, define and support Canadian families whose existence is the very foundation of our country and the basis for its continued existence.

Madam Speaker, Hockey Canada has been involved in international hockey for 20 years. NHL players donate their services.
I have asked several ministers repeatedly for the complete books and records of Hockey Canada: revenues, expenses, tax receipts, sponsorships, rink board advertising, et cetera.
The U.S. government through the FBI has been gathering this information on Hockey Canada for three years. Why is the Government of Canada not interested in satisfying the NHL players who were involved in these tournaments and who want to see the records?
I believe taking three years to react on the Hockey Canada file is too long.

Madam Speaker, on behalf of myself, my family, members of this House and the people of Canada I wish to convey to our sovereign, Queen Elizabeth II, the Queen of Canada, our warmest best wishes for the holiday season and above all for a most happy, healthy and peaceful 1993.
The past year, the 40th year of the Queen's reign, has been an exceedingly trying and stressful one for her, but through it all she has continued to personify and to demonstrate the finest qualities of the human spirit, qualities which are best demonstrated at times of adversity.
As each of us has our own personal problems and difficulties, times of trouble bring us together. It is at times like this that we can truly appreciate what the Queen symbolizes to us and how exceedingly well she fulfils her role and her responsibilities.
Our thoughts and our prayers are with her. God save the Queen.

December 11, 1992

Madam Speaker, the emergency response program of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, announced a couple of weeks ago, was certainly a step in the right direction. It will ease the financial situation for many people, but it excludes some people who really ought to have been included.
For example, seven fishermen at Lord's Cove will not qualify despite their long attachment with the fishery running from 12 years to as much as 46 years. There is no argument that the program does what it sets out to do. It eases the pain. I applaud the minister for that, but he must now realize that some people who ought to have been included have unfairly been falling through the cracks.

Madam Speaker, last night the Prime Minister, in an address to Harvard University, indicated that Canada had 1 per cent of the world's population and yet provided 10 per cent of the world's peacekeeping efforts. I support Canada's role in peacekeeping for in many ways keeping peace abroad is similar to keeping peace in our own country.
However many constituents are concerned with our level of involvement. This comes at a time when our debt seems to be in a critical situation thereby stifling our ability to deal with many of our own problems.
Canadians are unaware of the participation of other countries in what should be a shared role. Many of my constituents are asking Canada to reconsider the extent of our involvement in international peacekeeping and be guided by the principle that charity begins at home.

Madam Speaker, next Monday marks the sixth anniversary of the founding of Rural Dignity.
In the last six years its members have fought tirelessly on behalf of rural Canada. Rural Dignity has helped to draw attention to the issues affecting rural Canada. Whether it has been the closure of rural post offices, the loss of VIA Rail services or cuts to health care in rural areas, Rural Dignity has been there. Equally important has been Rural Dignity's ability to make people aware of the seriousness of the problems facing rural Canada.
Today most Canadians and even some politicians realize that if we do not act soon many of our rural communities will not survive. Increasingly people in rural communities across Canada have made it clear that they are not going to let their communities be shut down without a fight.
Today the people of St. Clement, Quebec, are occupying their post office to prevent Canada Post from shutting it down. In my own constituency of Moose Jaw-Lake Centre the people of Shamrock are working to force Canada Post to respect the wishes of the community and keep the post office open.
The renewed determination of Canadians in rural areas who fight for the survival of rural Canada is due in no small part to the work of Rural Dignity.

Madam Speaker, ever since coming to Ottawa I have pressed the case for nuclear development in New Brunswick because of two equally compelling considerations.
First, the existing Point Lepreau nuclear reactor is rated as one of the best operating units in the entire world and New Brunswick's nuclear management capability is highly regarded as the right environment for carrying out the construction of the Candu III prototype.
Second, the future potential for modular construction and sale of Candu III units world-wide offers New Brunswick an unprecedented economic horizon that would be difficult to match in any other way.
December 11. 1992

Unfortunately the provincial government in New Brunswick has apparently not been satisfied during negotiations that acceptable costs and guarantee provisions have been forthcoming and has been unwilling to consummate an agreement with AECL and the federal government.
Without question, in my view, New Brunswick is now on the verge of missing a compelling opportunity. I call on my colleagues in both the federal and provincial governments to make extraordinary efforts to salvage these nuclear power negotiations between them.

As well, yesterday at the United Nations General Assembly our minister in charge of development assistance presented the commemorative resolution marking recognition of 1993 as the International Year of Indigenous Peoples.
Citizens of the world know-certainly the Government of Canada must know-that Canada will be known internationally by its actions, not its rhetoric.

Madam Speaker, I was speaking to Bryan Cousi-neau, York Regional Police Chief yesterday. He said that changes to the Young Offenders Act, specifically with respect to age limits, is a priority. He explained that youths of 16 and 17 years who commit crimes know exactly what they are doing and should be punished more severely. Right now these young people commit dangerous crimes, armed with weapons, and they walk away with incredibly lenient sentences.

The federal government must introduce changes to the Young Offenders Act so that these young people will be tried in adult court and will be dealt some harsh penalties for their criminal activities.
We need to support our police officers and make sure we are doing everything we can to help them do their jobs more effectively.

Madam Speaker, last April I urged the Canadian government to support at the United Nations sixth committee a proposal for an international criminal court.
I said at the time that it was an idea whose time had come. I am pleased to report to the House today that the government has indeed actively supported such a court. I would like to congratulate the minister of external affairs.
Last week, some 130 experts in this field, including 12 parliamentarians from all across the world, members of Parliamentarians for Global Action, attended the UN sponsored conference in Siracusa, Italy.
That conference urged as a first step to such an international criminal court the establishment by the UN or the CSCE in Europe of an ad hoc tribunal to try allegations of genocide and war crimes in Yugoslavia.

Madam Speaker, we are presently discussing the North American free trade agreement and its effect on Canadian trade and its workers.
I want to discuss trade that is already occurring. This week a firm in my riding announced the contract for the sale of prefabricated homes to Mexico. This contract will in its entirety create employment for some 340 Canadian people over 30 months. It will use existing industrial space and does not require new technology.
What it does require is recognition of the emerging purchasing power of Mexico, recognition of the material that must be used and the ingenuity to design a structure that can be packaged and shipped to Mexico at a competitive price.
In this case Festival Developments Group Limited has done all of these. The startling size of this contract makes it special. The total sale of 27,500 units will create a $179 million export to Mexico with opportunities to expand it.
Canadian skill and Canadian ingenuity can compete in Mexico and around the world.

Madam Speaker, we New Brunswickers are very proud of the support for the motion on language equality in New Brunswick.
I listened with interest to what my leader, the Minister of Employment and Immigration and my colleague from Acadie-Bathurst said and I fully agree with them.

The population in my riding is comprised of both French and English people who have been living together in harmony since the time of settlement.
Today's motion simply recognizes something that these people have known for hundreds of years, that both linguistic communities are equal.

The support for this motion is a message and a challenge to the rest of Canada. I urge Canada to unite in a lasting way and accept the challenge. Such unity would be a model throughout the world.
I am proud to have had an opportunity to participate and support this motion.

Madam Speaker, this fall I attended the 10th anniversary of the Chemainus' Festival of Murals. Chemainus notes with amusement Welland's attempt to claim the title Mural City of Canada. While I congratulate Welland on the attempt, I feel I must point out a few facts.
Chemainus is recognized internationally as the Mural Capital of the World. The town and its citizens combine history, culture and the arts to save what could have become a ghost town.
Chemainus, like so many small communities, was a single industry town dependent on forestry. When the economy slowed and the industry began to change, Chemainus suffered.
This was a town that would not die. Instead, through the inspiration of Karl Schultz and others and the hard work of many, Chemainus was born again. Now, after 10 years, 32 murals and thousands of visitors, Chemainus is known as the little town that did.
Its Festival of Murals Society has gone on to help other communities start mural projects of their own in Steubenville, Ohio; Bowenshire, Queensland, Australia; and Welland, the mural capital of Ontario.

Madam Speaker, four and a half years ago the Minister of the Environment committed to support the establishment of a park to preserve the Rouge River Valley lands in Scarborough.
The government at that time pledged $10 million to the park initiative. Since then the provincial government has decided to establish the park and a multipartite advisory committee has recommended that the land base of the park be 20,000 acres in Scarborough and Markham.
This park proposal will create Canada's largest urban parkland to protect the natural environment and wildlife including 55 species of fish, 200 species of birds, 28 species of mammals, 700 species of plants, wetlands and forests.
Oral Questions
The provincial government will make a critical decision next week on the future of the park proposal. We ask the government to renew its commitment to the Rouge Valley, participate in the planning and management of the park and commit surplus federal lands in the area to land swaps to build the necessary park land base.

Madam Speaker, one year ago Canada said its children are important by ratifying the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Since ratification this government has taken concrete steps to honour its commitment to children and their families.
In May 1992 Canada introduced its action plan for children and announced the child development initiative, a group of long-term programs to address the conditions of risk that threaten the well-being and development of one Canadian child in five.
In addition, the new child tax benefit to begin in January 1993 represents an increase of $2.1 billion in federal government support for children and families over the next five years.
Children are our most precious resource. These initiatives demonstrate the Government of Canada's resolve in meeting its obligation to children and their families.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, since it is the last sitting day, I would like to wish you and everybody in the House of Commons a very Merry Christmas and happy holidays.
My question is for the Acting Prime Minister. We read in the press that Senator Lowell Murray, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, confirmed yesterday that the Prime Minister is about to make ten Senate appointments. He said: "We want to be more at ease to pass controversial legislation like Bill C-91 and NAFTA".

Oral Questions
Everybody remembers that in 1984, the right hon. member for Vancouver Quadra, when he was Prime Minister, made some appointments in the fifth year of his mandate. At that time, the present Prime Minister said that the Prime Minister had an option and it was not normal to do something like that in the fifth year of the mandate.
I ask the Acting Prime Minister why it would be moral in 1992 to do something like that when it was absolutely immoral according to the Prime Minister in 1984. Why would the Prime Minister do today that which he used as an instrument to win the election in 1984?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. Leader of the Opposition knows, many of the appointments having to do with the contents of the referendum were held in abeyance until such time as the decision on the referendum was held. Therefore, there is a backlog of appointments in a number of areas.
The hon. Leader of the Opposition knows the outcome of the referendum which involved very substantial changes to the structure and the composition of the Senate. Of course, with that having been rejected by the people of Canada, the institutional structures of the House of Commons and the Senate remain the same.
There is not only an obligation but also a responsibility for the Prime Minister to fulfil his duties commensurate with the Constitution and the traditions of the past.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, that is exactly my point. Now we are in the fifth year of the mandate and that was the big argument made by the Prime Minister in 1984. I do not question the legality or the constitutionality. I am talking about the morality of doing such a thing.
The Prime Minister was so offended in 1984 and a lot of people claim that is what made the difference in the election. I want to know from the Acting Prime Minister what makes it moral in 1992 when it was absolutely immoral in 1984?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is quite a
difference between filling the Senate on the eve of an election versus an election that may be held anywhere from six to ten months down the road.
If we want to talk about democratic morality we could not get a better example than the Leader of the Opposition going into a constituency and hand-picking his favourite candidate to represent the Liberal Party in the next election. That is quite an example of political morality.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):

I had
the backing of 90 per cent of the members who were delegates.

I shall return to this question.
In 1984, the government was in the third or fourth month of its fifth year. Today this government is in its fifth year and it is getting ready to do exactly what they reproached the government for in 1984.
Will the Acting Prime Minister inform the Prime Minister that Canadians do not want this kind of abuse of power by a government that has absolutely no legitimacy now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is quite interesting to note the hon. member is now backtracking on a spirited defence of his former leader which he took back in 1984.
Let me just assure the hon. Leader of the Opposition. He says he has the backing of 90 per cent of his members. The Prime Minister has the backing of 100 per cent of his members.
Hear, hear.
And they are all going down with him too.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.

All the excuses in the world will not cover up the fact that the Prime Minister and this government are desperately clinging to power in the fifth year of a mandate.
Canada has the highest unemployment rate in the industrialized world. We have more jobless Canadians at this point than at any other time in our 125-year history. Food banks are bursting at the seams.
If the Conservative government has done such a great job on the economy why is the jobless situation so absolutely heartbreaking?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is interesting that the hon. member is on this kick of bad-mouthing Canada when the United Nations says we are the best country in the world in which to live.
The hon. member talks about the high level of unemployment and yes, it is too high. We are taking steps to bring it down. I also remind the hon. member that there are 12,252,000 Canadians who are working and there are 1.8 million self-employed Canadians. That too is a record.

Madam Speaker, I am not bad-mouthing Canada. I believe in Canada. I think a new government could give Canada a chance again.

We know that more than a million children are lining up for food and clothing over the Christmas period. We know that unemployed Canadians are being treated savagely by this government.
If your government's policies are so good, why are you not ready to go to the people directly to find out if you have their support in an election?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, she will not have to worry. She will have a chance to go to the people.
We had the same invitations going into the 1988 election. Many members opposite were sorry they badgered us to call the election because when the dust settled they ended up over there and we ended up over here.
Oral Questions
Certainly there are difficulties. The impact of the economic slowdown has had an effect on all Canadians.
I remind the hon. member that federal spending on social programs which really address some of the difficult programs that he referred to has increased. Spending by the federal government between the period 1984-85 and 1991-92 increased from $44.6 billion to $66.8 billion. That was an increase of 5.9 per cent, and that was per year, when program spending was averaging at a growth rate of about 4 per cent on an annual basis.
In terms of the incidence of low income, 1984 to 1990, the 1984 figures had a percentage of 18.1 per cent. In
1990	it was down to 14.6 per cent. It went up a little bit in
1991	to 16 per cent, reflecting again the economic slowdown, but conditions are better today than they were in 1984 when we assumed office.

Madam Speaker, this morning young homeless Canadians are forced to live in tents out in front of the Parliament Buildings in the middle of a snowstorm. Some members find humorous the fact that homeless people exist in this country. I know people find this very, very funny. As young children line up at food banks which is their source of food today, 1992 will be remembered as the worst year in government performance since 1981 when the Liberals were on that side of the House.
Remember then there were a million people unemployed and now it is 1.6 million people. There were huge debts and now we have larger debts facing this country.
Will the Minister of Finance admit that the old ways have proven to be a complete disaster? Will he use the next six weeks to rethink his policies and come back with a new initiative to get people back working again?

Well, Madam Speaker, the hon. member wants government to bury its head in the sand and ignore the realities of the North American and world economic situation. We are going through a period of economic downturn because there is a global slowdown.
As a matter of fact, we are projecting a growth rate of 2.5 per cent for 1993. The combined growth rate anticipated for the European Economic Community is 1 per

cent. The world growth rate is at 1 per cent. Canada has been affected by that.
We are taking steps as outlined in the economic statement last week to invest in people, business and infrastructure and to encourage more trade. We are a trading country. Naturally our performance in trade is very important. We are investing in productivity enhancement, but most important we are investing in skills upgrading and retraining.
That is the focus, because the focus of the changing economy compels us to adapt to those changes and that is precisely what we are doing.

Madam Speaker, the Minister of Finance can use all the figures he wants. The reality is that unemployment in Canada is remaining at unprecedented rates. The predictions are that it is not going to change for the next couple of years.
As a matter of fact, the manufacturing index this morning indicates that Canadian manufacturers are losing market share domestically as well as on world markets at a higher rate than most other industrialized countries. The situation is worsening.
As he and the Prime Minister and their colleagues do a lot of walking in the snow during the next six weeks contemplating their employment futures, they should give some consideration to the plight of the unemployed in this country.
Will he consider the tens of thousands, yea millions, of people concerned about the future in terms of their own employment and change his policies?
If he refuses to do that, will he do the right thing and urge the Prime Minister to call an election so we can change this government and get a government in that will actually change course and put people back to work?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I can only take it that the hon. member is suggesting we follow the same kind of policies as the New Democratic Party is following in the province of Ontario. That is an anti-business attitude which has driven business out of this country into the United States and has disrupted orderly growth and orderly transition. That is not the course of action we intend to follow.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs. It is about jobs, namely the 10 vacancies in the Senate.
During the referendum campaign the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, the Prime Minister, most people of this Elouse and indeed the people of this country found the present unelected Senate to be absolutely unacceptable in a modern democracy.
In light of that, and I know the Prime Minister has the constitutional right to appoint senators-I do not want that for an answer-I wonder if the minister would suggest to the Prime Minister that there be a moratorium on the appointment of all senators until either we reform the other place, the Senate, or if we cannot reform the Senate, then abolish it; in other words, no more senators until it is reformed or abolished.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I think that such a recommendation would be quite inappropriate. We had proposals for change. They were considered. They were extensive. They were rejected. We must now make do with the Senate that is in place.
We cannot allow the referendum result which stopped one attempt at reform to also stop the business of Canada, which could be the result if we simply allowed the atrophy of one of the two institutions established by the Constitution of Canada as being part of the Parliament of Canada.
I am sure the hon. member understands that. I know he was a believer in whole-hearted reform. I am sure he would not associate himself with people like Preston Manning who are suggesting that after they had defeated a proposal for whole-hearted reform, we should go forward with some kind of half-hearted, partial reform.
December 11, 1992

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Only a few steps from Parliament Hill in my riding of Ottawa Centre, homeless and jobless people are living on Wellington Street in a makeshift tent.
Why was there nothing in the recent budget to help these homeless young people and others in cities across Canada so that they may have a dignified shelter over their heads?

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows very well that the federal government puts in in excess of $2 billion on an annual basis toward housing in Canada. It is a very, very large commitment and it has been growing over the years.
I do not know what the hon. member has in mind specifically, but here again, the best way to enhance confidence and optimism is to create the opportunities for job creation. We took a number of steps and announced a number of initiatives in the statement on Wednesday which will help small business and which will help individuals train and adjust to the changing environment. It constitutes a massive program of complementing the changes that are already taking place and being advanced by the private sector.
What we are proposing here is a partnership regime between the two levels of government, the private sector and the workers of Canada to deal with this very important challenge that can be turned into enormous opportunities for our country.

Madam Speaker, if this government's policies are so great, how come in Montreal 18,000 children need food baskets this Christmas, while in Quebec City another 4,000 are going to need those baskets and in my own riding of Mount Royal, 540 people will go to the Multi-caf food bank for their Hanukkah and Christmas baskets, now without meat and now without milk. They have had to put in powdered milk because they cannot afford real milk. That is a total shame.
Oral Questions
What are this government's economic policies going to do to answer the needs of these families? Is this the way we have to live in the province of Quebec to feed our families?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President

Madam Speaker, I say to the hon. member that the federal government is transferring in excess of $39 billion annually to the provinces in the form of cash transfers and tax points. That is a lot of money. Those transfers are not going down. They are going up.
What we are doing as well, as we outlined in the economic plan last week, is taking a number of steps to bolster growth, to encourage confidence, to create jobs and to generate economic activity. I rise today on behalf of the Secretary of State for External Affairs, who was unable to fly to Ottawa this morning because of the snow storm. On her behalf I am now announcing the government's decision about Canada's participation in the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Cyprus.
After extensive consultations with the United Nations, Greece, Turkey, as well as Greek and Turkish Cypriots, the government has informed the Secretary-General of the United Nations that Canada will withdraw its troops from Cyprus beginning June of 1993, the withdrawal to be completed by September.
For the past 28 years, from the very beginning of the UN peacekeeping operation in Cyprus, thousands of Canadian men and women have displayed extraordinary competence, fairness and calm under pressure in the cause of peace. Their presence in Cyprus has been a powerful symbol of Canada's commitment to peace and security in the world. It has been a source of honour and pride, not only for those serving there but for all Canadians.
I am sure I speak for all members of the House and for all Canadians when I say that these Canadian men and women, as well as their families, are those to whom Canada owes a large debt of gratitude for their dedication and their professionalism, and to the 24 who died in the service of peace for their sacrifice.
December li, 1992

Beyond our contribution of troops and equipment, Canada has spared no effort to help the Secretary-General find a peaceful solution to this dispute. As recently as this year, the Secretary of State for External Affairs visited Cyprus, Greece and Turkey in May to press all parties concerned to work with the Secretary-General to that end.
She renewed our plea to Cypriots at the UN General Assembly in September and indicated that our patience was running short. We were deeply disappointed that the discussions under the Secretary-General's guidance have not been successful. In a unanimous resolution on November 25, the Security Council stated that the present status quo is not acceptable.
The government has also taken into account the report and appreciates the effort by a group of parliamentarians, led by the hon. member for Don Valley East, that provided the Secretary of State for External Affairs with useful information on the current situation in Cyprus.
After 28 years of service in Cyprus, after 28 years of watching both sides in the dispute being either unable or unwilling to negotiate a political solution, after 28 years of significant expenditures to maintain troops and equipment in that region without any measurable progress, it was time to face facts and come to certain conclusions.
Our experience in Cyprus has taught us many lessons.
One of the most important is that parties in a dispute must understand that there are limits to the duration of any peacekeeping operation. Peacekeeping must never be considered as an end in itself or as a substitute for political leadership, negotiation and honourable compromise. The basis for any peacekeeping operation has always been an agreement by the parties involved to work toward a political settlement. Whether or not Canadian troops remain in Cyprus, Greek and Turkish Cypriots bear the ultimate responsibility for resolving the dispute.
It appears that instead of taking advantage of the peace and order which the UN mission has afforded, some political leaders have used the presence of UN forces to avoid making the difficult choices, to avoid making the compromises required to ensure peaceful coexistence. At a time when there are increasing demands for peacekeeping around the world, we must
Routine Proceedings
ensure that we establish our priorities carefully and manage our resources and contributions effectively.
In deciding to withdraw our troops, we are not saying that the United Nations should put an end to its peacekeeping mission in Cyprus. That is a matter for the Security Council, the Secretary General and the parties involved to consider.
Furthermore, I assure the House that we will continue to support the Secretary-General's ongoing efforts to find a peacefully negotiated solution. In that regard, Canada once again calls upon the parties involved to implement Security Council resolution 789 and to work with the Secretary-General. If circumstances change, Canada would consider contributing directly to new UN efforts toward a peaceful settlement in Cyprus or to its implementation.
As the Secretary of State for External Affairs told the UN General Assembly last September, the Government of Canada endorses the Secretary-General's agenda for peace, in particular the peacemaking and peacekeeping themes of that document. That is why Canada will continue to play a leading role in international efforts to secure peace. We are turning a page in this particular chapter of our history. Our passion for peace remains as fervent as it was 30 years ago when our soldiers donned the blue beret and went to Cyprus.
With over 4,000 troops participating in peacekeeping missions from Cambodia to Bosnia, from Croatia to Central America and the Middle East, the words Canada and peacekeeping will always be closely associated in the eyes of Canadians and in the eyes of the world.

I do not think the secretary of state is fair to Canadians. The Greek Cypriot side is spending $1 million a day on purchasing military equipment. If the UN peacekeeping forces pull out of the buffer zone, what is going to happen? I am quite sure that some of the 35,000 Turkish troops will start occupying the buffer zone.

that is all the opposition is asking-that a just and viable solution is found.
I mentioned in my question in Question Period today that President Vassiliou and Mr. Denktash had negotiations all summer. The talks did not break down completely. The talks were suspended because there is a presidential election in February. Both sides agreed, together with the Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, that these talks will resume in March under the careful guidance of the Secretary-General himself.
Why not wait to withdraw until a solution is found? A solution is around the corner. Why not wait until such time that another country will help us and send some peacekeeping troops in there? Unfortunately our secretary of slate blew it again. I wish I could have congratulated her in the spirit of Christmas, but no, our image in the international community is suffering. The secretary of state does not bring such important issues, where our military is involved, to be debated in this House first.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to put the position of the New Democratic Party on the government's announcement on the record.
I can actually find reason to congratulate the minister. We on this side, certainly our party, do appreciate that the minister has chosen to make this announcement in the House of Commons. It demonstrates that the government or at least the minister can learn rapidly. A week ago the Secretary of State for External Affairs chose to make the announcement on Somalia downstairs in a press conference while the House was in session. I want to say that we appreciate that the minister has made the announcement here in the House today.
The next step for the government is to decide that important decisions of this kind will actually be brought to the House with a resolution in order that the House can pass judgment and can debate the issue before the government simply announces it. However, we appreciate the rate of learning demonstrated by this minister in the last week.
Canada has contributed to UN peacekeeping in Cyprus since 1974. Thousands of Canadian service personnel have served in Cyprus since that time. Thousands of families have made the sacrifice of separation in order that Canadians can participate in keeping the peace in
Routine Proceedings
Cyprus. Twenty-one Canadian Forces personnel died in Cyprus in the service of their country and in the service of the United Nations and we honour their sacrifice and their commitment.
I should take this opportunity to note the fact that many Canadian veterans of UN peacekeeping operations are disappointed that the Canadian government has so far failed to strike a Canadian service medal for peacekeeping under the United Nations in recognition of that service. The Canadian Peacekeepers Veterans Association, headed by James MacMillan-Murphy in my riding, has taken up this issue and I hope the government will respond to it.
The minister has today announced that Canada is withdrawing its forces from the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus. It has done so with no replacement indicated. It has done so with no resolution of the dispute that took Canada and the United nations into Cyprus and it has done so with no assurance that this withdrawal will not make the situation worse. The government has said that UN peacekeeping is part of the problem. I submit that is simply wrong and that there is no evidence for that statement. UN peacekeeping is what is maintaining peace and security for the people of Cyprus.
The parliamentary committee to which my friend from Parkdale-High Park referred gave that evidence this week to the House of Commons, an all-party committee. It spoke to Cypriots from all sides and said that the UN peacekeeping force is vital for peace and security in Cyprus. In the minister's announcement there was no item of evidence against that proposition.
I submit that what the government is doing here is pandering to a natural war weariness by Canadians of the contribution that has been made over these many years. I submit that it is incumbent upon the government to show leadership to Canadians on this difficult issue and to say that we are performing a vital role and we must keep it up until either our forces are replaced with others or until there is a just and honourable solution to the dispute. As long as we are providing a useful service, we should stay in Cyprus.
We oppose this resolution because all parties say our contribution is vital to peace. We say that this announcement comes at a particularly delicate time while there are initiatives to try to resolve this dispute. There will be an election in Cyprus in February. The peace discussions

December 11, 1992
Routine Proceedings
have been adjourned until March and I think the government has a duty to those from Canada who have sacrificed over the years in service in Cyprus not to come to this House until it can give assurance to the House and to the country that what we are doing is part of a solution and not simply an abandonment of responsibilities.
If we leave now or in 1993, as the government has announced, there is a real risk that the situation will blow up again and that all we are doing is saying, particularly to the Turkish side, wait long enough and our arms will again be able to impose our solution in Cyprus. That is wrong and it is a position that this government should have rejected.
It is said that this costs too much. It is said the government trots out the $14 million a year that this costs. As the member for Parkdale-High Park said, this is modest compared to the costs that may occur as a result of this decision.
It is modest to the billions of dollars that this government wastes in the Department of National Defence, including the latest outrage on helicopters.
I regret this decision. Our party regrets this decision and we hope the government will use the Christmas season to reconsider.
Mr. Speaker, a point of order.
The hon. member for Saint-Denis, on a point of order.

Mr. Speaker, thank you for allowing this point of order. I am well acquainted with the Standing Orders, and I know that unfortunately, there can no further speeches by members.

I was elected in 1964 and we have had Canadians in Cyprus since 1964 and it so happens that I have been following the issue since 1964. Therefore, I very much regret that the rules of the House do not allow more participation because the rule is very clear: only the minister's statement plus two members, one from each parly, can speak. I am unable to participate, but I shall at the first opportunity since I sit on the committee on management of the House.
The very able chairman from Edmonton Southwest is here and I will certainly raise the issue at the first opportunity at the committee of management of the House that we may see the time has now come to change the rule which deprives a full debate, maybe at least an hour debate of some kind, with more participation from the House on very specific and important issues of international importance. I have a great deal of interest and Canada has a great deal of interest for its reputation.
Unfortunately, such is the rule, such is life. I want strongly to be on record that I very much regret that we are withdrawing at this time. We should have waited until at least March to know what would have taken place.

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present, in both official languages, the third report of the Special Committee on Electoral Reform.
I would point out to the House that it contains close to 100 pages of amendments. It is an interim report and deals with the issue of who shall vote and how they shall vote. There are a few other items but that is the primary thrust of it.
The committee has engaged itself in close to 31 separate long meetings on the draft report alone because the work is so detailed in trying to provide for Canadians a better system of voting and protection against fraud at some kind of reasonable price.
The big change to enable Canadians who are away from their normal home to vote more easily under those conditions. That will include Canadians who are in some
December 11. 1992

other location temporarily within the country as well as Canadians who reside abroad.

We are also anticipating as committee members that the government will produce a bill for us to consider immediately upon return in the new year so that these changes can be implemented in time for the next election. provided mixed emotions for us. We experienced moments of pride and we experienced moments of sorrow in what we saw. We felt compassion and some helplessness during our visit. Perhaps this report will in some way help.
