speechtext:
Madam Chairman, I believe there is disposition on the part of the parties to make a short statement at the committee stage. Then if there are questions I would be prepared to take them.
I would like to very briefly outline the provisions of the Gwich'in Land Claim Settlement Act, Bill C-94.1 will, in the interest of time, keep this very short.
This bill will give the force of law of the Gwich'in comprehensive land claim agreement, of which I have a copy and which was tabled in this House on November 26. It is a historic agreement formally signed by the Governments of Canada, the Northwest Territories and the Gwich'in Tribal, council on April 22 of this year.
Under the terms of this accord the 2,200 Gwich'in people living in the Mackenzie River area, largely in the communities of Aklavik, Inuvik, Arctic Red River, and Fort McPherson, will receive title to more than 22,000 square kilometres of land in the Northwest Territories, and title to more than 1,550 square kilometres of their ancestral homelands in the Yukon Territory.
Bill C-94 also allows the Gwich'in to play a major role in managing the renewal resources of the area. It provides sub-surface rights to 6,100 kilometres of land in the Northwest Territories, and exclusive rights to certain commercial wildlife harvesting activities.
The financial benefits include a tax-free payment of $75 million in 1990 dollars to be paid out over the 15-year period following adoption of this bill. It also gives them an annual share of resource royalties at the level of 7.5 per cent on the first $2 million of resource earnings and 1.5 per cent on sums beyond that level of earnings as resources are extracted from the Gwich'in lands within the Mackenzie River Valley, and also a 15-year subsidy of property taxes on the undeveloped lands known as Gwich'in lands within municipal boundaries.
Under the terms of this bill federal, territorial, and municipal laws will continue to apply to the Gwich'in and their land until a self-government agreement has been successfully negotiated and brought forward to this House.
Those terms form the backbone of the land claim settlement, the backbone of Bill C-94, a bill whose merit all parties will acknowledge.
In every respect, this bill represents a great and historic step of progress. Bill C-94 provides the Gwich'in with a role in the development of the north. It does this through the creation of a number of specific management boards. It provides economic opportunities beyond their traditional vocations, a voice in the ongoing management of those resources, and provides for a dispute settlement mechanism to resolve disagreements which may arise with governments.
Let me just add that while the Gwich'in are exchanging certain undefined hunting, fishing and trapping rights contained in the existing Treaty 11 for the more clearly defined benefits of Bill C-94, all other treaty rights contained in Treaty 11, which was signed in 1921, will continue in place. These other treaty rights include the provision for annual treaty payments, education rights and other social treaty benefits.
The settlement of aboriginal land claims has been a major priority of this government. In recognition of the vital necessity to settle these land claim issues, necessary for the future of aboriginal peoples and the economic development of Canada, this government made the resolution of comprehensive claims the first pillar of the agenda of native initiatives which the Prime Minister presented in this House in September 1990.
Therefore, this legislation represents the first regional land claim settlement resulting from the prolonged negotiations with the Dene and Metis people of the western Arctic. In that regard the Gwich'in are truly pioneers. They have broken the ice and set an example for others in the western Arctic to follow.
In conclusion, I would like to personally compliment President Willard Hagen of the Gwich'in Tribal Council, Chief James Ross of the Fort McPherson Band and other members of their negotiating team and board for their very positive, optimistic, and confident approach to concluding this agreement.
Hon. colleagues, Madam Chairman, I would ask you to lend your support to the legislation before us today, which received a 94 per cent ratification vote from the eligible voting members of the Gwich'in nation last year. I call on members to facilitate quick passage. I do so especially because of the economic and human importance of this agreement to the Gwich'in people. I note that the Gwich'in elders will receive benefits before the Christmas period if this legislation is passed today.
December 11, 1992

I trust that hon. members will be prepared to give their consent to completing the passage of the bill through all stages today, including the final passage and referral to the other place. I encourage hon. members to give their complete co-operation to this important initiative.

Madam Chairman, I am honoured to rise to speak to the second reading and passage of Bill C-94, which deals with the Gwich'in land claim. I am honoured to have the opportunity to speak on this comprehensive land claim legislation. As the minister has mentioned, the Gwich'in people are the first to reach a regional land claim agreement in the Northwest Territories since the failure of the comprehensive Dene-Metis final agreement.
There are now two other native organizations in my riding of the Western Arctic, the Sahtu Tribal Council and the Dogrib Tribal Council, that have also initiated land claims negotiations based on the former comprehensive claim final agreement.
The Gwich'in people are very proud of their agreement, which is the final product of many years of very hard work and their tireless efforts to seek and achieve an agreement that would give them an immense opportunity for a financially secure future. The Gwich'in people are looking forward to using this agreement to better their lives.
As parliamentarians we can and are obligated to assist the Gwich'in people in obtaining this goal.
Negotiations have spanned seven generations of the Gwich'in people. Their struggle began in 1921 under Chief Julius Salu of the Tetlit Gwich'in and Paul Niditchi of the Gwich'a Gwich'in who were signatories to Treaty 11 on July 26 and July 28, 1921, respectively, in the communities of Arctic Red River and Fort McPherson.
The Gwich'in people had believed Treaty 11 could be a peace and friendship treaty until it was discovered that there was a misunderstanding in the translating of the treaty from the spoken word to the written page, with Ottawa interpreting the treaty as a surrender by the Gwich'in people of their lands and their cultural identity.
Government Orders
Their language, religion and traditional values which had survived for thousands of years were almost lost.
A strong and proud people, the Gwich'in have stood peacefully against those outside forces which sought economic wealth in taking their non-renewable resources and using their water and lands, some of which have sustained damage. They have survived against the wealthy and misguided anti-fur lobby groups which callously and dishonestly oppose the harvesting of fur and animal hides with precious little regard for the impact such deceitful and disrespectful campaigns have had upon the the Gwich'in, their values, traditions and their economic way of life.
It has been Gwich'in determination which has carried the Gwich'in people to this moment of the second reading of their legislation today. Theirs is an agreement which is the product of extensive negotiations conducted since the Government of Canada first accepted claims from the Dene and Metis in 1976 and 1977.
Using the 1990 agreement in principle as the basis for continuing negotiations, the Gwich'in of the Mackenzie Delta region and Canada began negotiations in December, 1990 and initialled a comprehensive agreement on July 13, 1991.
Special thanks and congratulations should be made to the people of the Gwich'in Nation who turned out to vote, as the minister mentioned, and to the support of the Gwich'in Clan between September 16 to 20, 1991. Of the 1,122 eligible voters, 1,021 cast a ballot and 960 voted in favour of the agreement; a very impressive 91 per cent turnout and a 94 per cent vote in favour of the agreement.
Appropriately, the historic signing of the Gwich'in comprehensive land claim agreement took place on April 22, 1992 at the Chief Julius School in the community of Fort McPherson. It should be noted that at that time there were many officials there, including territorial officials, the leader, the hon. Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development as well as the member of Parliament for Western Arctic. Many respected elders who played an important role in the negotiation process were present and participated in the actual signing of the final agreement.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
The agreement is a celebration of the Gwich'in's culture and identity. After the signing, drum dances and fiddling dances and feasts were held in each of the communities of Fort McPherson, Aklavik, Inuvik and Arctic Red River, with the celebrations lasting for days. This agreement may not be the end of almost 20 years of negotiations or 70 years of struggle, but it is definitely a major step forward. The Gwich'in have negotiated a modern day treaty with more economic benefits, subsurface and surface ownership, regional powers in some cases, exclusive rights to hunting, trapping and fishing and clearly defined aboriginal rights. These provisions have been accepted and ratified by the majority of the Gwich'ins.
On the gains and provisions, the Gwich'in agreement represents significant gains for the Gwich'in people. They have within that particular agreement a flowthrough provision in section 3.1.5.
A general provision within the Gwich'in agreement protects the aboriginal identity of the Gwich'in people and within their legislation they are protected and included in the opportunity to benefit from or participate in any existing or future constitutional rights for aboriginal people which may also be applicable to them.
There is also the self-government framework in appendix B. The self-government framework agreement provides a broad range of aiiaiisjurisdictions over which the Gwich 'in may enter negotiation with the Government of Canada.
The framework agreement will allow the Gwich'in to discuss the transfer and delivery of programs, services such as education, training, language, revenue and taxation, health and social services and the administration of justice through a Gwich'in tribal justice system based upon traditional values. In years to come this aboriginal group will be recognized, its rights entrenched in the Constitution of Canada. There have been gains made from Treaty 11. Most Gwich'in Treaty 11 rights remain unaffected by the agreement.
On the question of land, the Gwich'in will receive title to 8,622 square miles of land in the Northwest Territories, including increased sub-surface rights and sub-surface resources, and an additional 600 square miles of land in the Yukon, which do not include sub-surface resources. They will receive $75 million over 15 years.
I urge the members of this House for speedy passage of this legislation in that there are specific provisions for
the elders to be affected immediately upon the passage of this legislation.
It also touches on the harvesting rights; many detailed rights in Gwich'in settlement area, including exclusive trapping of fur bearers, harvesting preferences on all species, exclusive harvesting on Gwich'in titled lands.
There is also the issue of expropriation. The quantum of land that was agreed upon in this land claims agreement is guaranteed to the Gwich'in forever. Even in the unlikely event that the government should need to expropriate a portion of land within the settlement area, this guarantee will stand.
Management rights and economic opportunities also exist. Gwich'in are guaranteed 50 per cent on management boards, including renewable resources, land use planning, environmental assessment, land and water regulation. The Gwich'in see this as a very positive gain which now gives the Gwich'in an equal say and a voice.
First time economic opportunities will now exist in a number of areas. They will have a role in development resolving disputes between government and Gwich'in and the amendments of the treaty. The Gwich'in believe that where no provisions existed before, now the Gwich'in have guaranteed consultation by developers on a variety of matters. There is an arbitration panel should there be a difference in interpretation of the agreement, and amendments may be made by agreement between the Government of Canada and the Gwich'in.
On the subject of future concerns and the implementation process, I would like to raise a concern which has been expressed to me by the Gwich'in. The Gwich'in are concerned over the lack of a benefits package for the Gwich'in when developers wish to explore for oil and gas on Gwich'in lands. In the Gwich'in settlement area this is an essential requirement for any First Nation that wants to promote and establish some form of self-government.
Another pressing concern is the existence of outstanding loans against the financial compensation package. The Gwich'in have taken responsibility for 15 per cent of the $40 million loan to the Dene Metis acquired when attempting to obtain a comprehensive land claims agreement. The Gwich'in believe that the Government of Canada has a fundamental obligation to provide claimant groups with the necessary funds to procure a comprehensive land claim agreement.
December 11, 1992

In the best interests of both parties and in good faith of the negotiation process, I hope and trust that the Government of Canada will respect the reasonable timeframe allotted to the establishment and commencement of the implementation plan and the implementation committee as well as provide the adequate necessary funding to put the structure of the agreement into place.
As the Liberal critic of aboriginal affairs and as a member of Parliament responsible for the constituents' concerns in Western Arctic, I will monitor the progress made with respect to the process put into place within a reasonable length of time of the settlement legislation passage.
I would like to take a brief moment to describe for the members of the House today the four communities of the Mackenzie Delta, Aklavik, Inivuk, Fort MacPherson and Arctic Red. Aklavik, meaning place of the barren land grizzly in Inuktitut, is a community of 760. These are the communities that have worked closely together to achieve this land claim legislation.
The community of Aklavik, which grew out of a small trading post established by the Hudson Bay Company, quickly became the chief trapping, trading and transportation centre of the muskrat-rich Mackenzie Delta. Aklavik is probably known by many of its inhabitants as the town that would not die. If you are from Aklavik you commonly use the phrase in a situation that is tough, "never say die". As the town was relocated by the federal government to Inuvik due to the serious flooding and erosion, despite these problems many residents remain in Aklavik today. Inuvik is the largest Canadian community north of the Arctic Circle. With a population of 3,200, it was the Northwest Territories' first modem planned town.
Fort McPherson is located on the edge of the Gwich'in Dene territory on the Dempster highway and was named after Hudson's Bay trader Murdoch McPherson. With a population of 729, it remains to be one of the north's most important economic areas for hunting and trapping.
The small community of Arctic Red River, with 125 residents, is located where the Arctic Red River meets
Government Orders
the Mackenzie and has been a seasonal fishing camp for the Dene for centuries.
I would like to take the opportunity in closing to pay tribute to the people who have worked on this particular land claims legislation. Do I have time? I do not. I will save the tributes and the closing comments for the next part of my speech.

Madam Speaker, I would like to thank my colleagues who made the initial presentations from the Conservative and Liberal parties. I want the House to know that our party is prepared to support this legislation through third reading.
We recognize that the Gwich'in claim was overwhelmingly ratified by the Gwich'in people. As mentioned by the member for Western Arctic, on September 21, 1991 when the ratification vote was taken, 94 per cent of the Gwich'in people supported this claim and therefore I think the House has to recognize that the choice has been made by the Gwich'in people and that they overwhelmingly support the agreement with the national government. Only 5 per cent opposed. I wish we had achieved something like that in our own referendum.
Our party has always supported the idea of aboriginal land claims, not only because they resolve some outstanding social problems and problems of injustice that Canada has experienced with its aboriginal people, but also they are capable of bringing a substantial boost to economic development. Our party supports the settlement of claims because we know that through the settlement of lands and resources and also the financial compensation and royalties along the lines that the minister mentioned, a great deal of capital and the opportunity for economic development will be returned to the north.
The past northern policies of Liberal and Conservative governments have resulted in a decapitalization of the north where non-northern companies go into the north-mine, log, fish, hunt, whatever they do-and take the resources out of the north. They take the capital out of the north, they take the income out of the north and leave people in a relatively poor situation, with aboriginal people being the poorest among the poor.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
This agreement has an opportunity to reverse that kind of decapitalization process. The people who live in the Arctic have been living there for approximately 9,000 years. It was their home in the past. It is going to be their home in the future. Any kind of capital or income that returns to their investments on their own lands is going to be reinvested in the north and we are going to see the kind of economic growth that we have not seen in those areas for a long time.
Land claim settlements should be a key part of the economic strategy of Canada. They certainly can reverse the decapitalization trend that has taken place in the past.
I want to let members know that we do have some concerns about the federal government's involvement in the negotiation process. As my colleague the member for Western Arctic pointed out, in the past the federal government insisted that the Dene Metis groups in the western Arctic get together and negotiate a comprehensive land claim that would cover the whole area. After the expenditure of a great deal of money, time, research and negotiations, they came to an agreement. When that agreement was presented at Dettah in July 1990 it was rejected by the vast majority of the Dene Metis people. At that point the Gwich'in people walked out of the meeting and indicated that they were prepared to make their own settlement.
One of the reasons they did that, as the minister of Indian affairs will know, was because they said that their people had been suffering long enough. The land claim was going to bring about compensation, it was going to give them a land base, it was going to give them certain administrative and government powers which they felt they needed in order to get their people on the process of development. They were able to get into separate negotiations with the federal government with that as their priority.
Unfortunately it is a bit of a form of blackmail that the federal government is able to use when dealing with aboriginal people. On the one hand, aboriginal policy of the national government keeps native people in a state of perpetual poverty; it deprives them of the resources they need in order to pursue their economic development; but, on the other hand, they may be forced to accept land claim agreements in which they are required to extinguish their existing aboriginal rights. That creates
a serious problem, a serious dilemma, for aboriginal people.
The Gwich'in felt they could negotiate a claim which would help them with their economic and social programs, which would move them ahead as a people, and yet they were anticipating in the future that there would be some change on the part of the government, some change which would eliminate the blanket extinguishment provision or the right to extinguish aboriginal rights. They were taking a chance on the future in order to assist their people.
It is unfortunate that we still have, not necessarily the blanket extinguishment provision but the cede, lease and surrender kind of provision which still reduces aboriginal rights of people and requires them to surrender aboriginal rights when they enter into land claims.
Aboriginal people are the only people in this country who, in settling an outstanding grievance with the national government, are required to give up rights that have been assured to them under our Constitution. As far as I am concerned, it is unfair, it is a form of blackmail, and it should not be done.
I am pleased to see that there is another party in the House which has followed the lead of the New Democratic Party back in 1985 when we passed a resolution saying there should not be an extinguishment clause. Certainty it can be obtained by setting up forums through which native people can negotiate with the governments of Canada and the provinces, in order to make sure their rights are respected and their land and resource requirements are respected, given the changing circumstances.
We were also concerned, Madam Chairman, about the way third parties were consulted in the advancement of the Gwich'in land claim. We were concerned that, for example, 600 square miles of land became a part of the Gwich'in settlement in Yukon. The consultations that took place between the Government of Yukon and the federal government were not what we would call free and open and the parties were not considered equal in the process.
In fact, the federal government simply told the Government of Yukon that 600 square miles of the Yukon would become part of the Gwich'in settlement. In some cases that is more land than was received by groups of the Council of Yukon Indians during their settlement. They felt they were not being treated fairly and equitably in relation to the 600 square miles which was allocated as
December 11, 1992

part of the Gwich'in settlement. The minister may be able to respond to that.
With those concerns stated, we would like to pay tribute to all of those who were involved in the negotiating process. We think the result will be satisfactory to the Gwich'in people and will help them with their economic and social programs. It will make sure they can develop along the lines that they as a people in the Northwest Territories would like to develop. We wish them all the very best as a result of the outcome of this settlement.

Madam Chairman, I would like to make some comments about this bill.
Bill C-94 is a very important bill because it deals with aboriginal people. They have been neglected for so long that they merit more attention than we are giving them. This bill is presented here the same day as the House adjourns, and it has to pass through all stages.
I find it somewhat strange that the Department of Indian Affairs could not have introduced this bill a long time ago so that it would be debated on its merit. This leaves us very little time to do so.
As the Gwich'in people seem to be happy with this agreement, I am certainly supportive of this legislation. It is extremely important that the Gwich'in people be in accord with this legislation and as the minister and other members said, the people are in agreement.
However, I would like to mention something here. I have been to the north and I have seen the aboriginal people living in conditions that are so bad that the Third World countries would be ashamed of those conditions. Canada should put a priority on treating her own aboriginal people fairly. I do not think the federal government has done it in a proper way.
We have a huge Ministry of Indian Affairs consisting of almost 3,000 employees dealing day to day with this problem. They should have projects and situations that would improve the lives of the aboriginal people. If you go to the north, you see how appalling the situation is.
Government Orders
The aboriginal people cannot continue to live in such a way. It is late in the day and the minister brought this legislation in only half an hour ago but I would like to commend him for doing it. It is better late than never. I hope that he will take a lesson and deal with aboriginal affairs seriously and have other treaties signed to the satisfaction of the aboriginal people.
Therefore, I support the agreement and I congratulate the minister for bringing it in, even if it is late.

Clause agreed to.

Madam Chairman, in speaking before to Bill C-94, I did not get an opportunity to pay tribute to the people who were involved. I think this is very important.
The minister had the opportunity to do that, and I appreciate it, but a double tribute is not going to hurt in this case since the treaty was so much work.
The prominent Gwich'in have worked for the Gwich'in cause over the last 71 years. Chief Julius Salu of the Tetlit Gwich'in and Paul Niditchi of the Gwich'in were signatories to Treaty 11 in 1921.
The late Chief John Tetlitchi of the Tetlit Gwich'in represented the Tetlit Gwich'in for many years as chief and as a member of the legislative council of the Northwest Territories.
These individuals are outstanding leaders in their communities and basically drove the process at a time when it was not deemed to be either fashionable or the thing to do. Chief Johnny Charlie of the Tetlit Gwich'in represented the Tetlit Gwich'in for 10 years as chief and still plays an active role within the Gwich'in nation. He is also a very active member of the community as well as of the region. He is respected by many Dene people throughout the Northwest Territories and many aboriginal and non-aboriginal people.
Willard Hagen, president of the Gwich'in Tribal Council has led the Gwich'in since they decided to proceed with a comprehensive land claims agreement with the Government of Canada.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
James Ross, Chief of the Tetlit Gwich'in, was instrumental in obtaining a Dene Metis Comprehensive Land Claim Agreement on April 9, 1992, and later the Gwich'in Comprehensive Land Claim Agreement. Chief Ross has served his community and his people in various capacities over the last 10 years. He has been very active within the region and within the Northwest Territories, and is recognized for his work. He is fiercely determined, a very proud man, very intelligent and very eloquent on issues that affect his people, as well as his region and the north in general.
The former leaders of the Gwich'in who deserve special recognition and praise are: Chief Hyacinthe Andre of Arctic Red River, the late Chief Johnny Kaye of Fort McPherson, Chief Andrew Stewart of Aklavik, Chief Grace Blake of Arctic Red River, David Krutko, a former negotiator of the Gwich'in claim and former vice-president of the Metis Nation of the Northwest Territories, Margaret Donovan, former vice-president of the Gwich'in Tribal Council, Fred Koe, former negotiator of the Gwich'in claim and currently the MLA for Inuvik in the Northwest Territories Legislative Assembly, Richard Nerysoo, the MLA for the Mackenzie Delta in the Northwest Territories Legislative Assembly, and newly appointed cabinet minister for the Government of the Northwest Territories, as well as having been a former Minister of Justice and a government leader of the Northwest Territories.
As well, I would like to commend and congratulate the current leadership of the Gwich'in Nation, without whose efforts the Gwich'in Comprehensive Land Claim Agreement might not have been realized:
Willard Hagen; James Firth, Chief of Inuvik and vice-president of the Gwich'in Tribal Council; Robert Alexie Jr., vice-president of the Gwich'in Tribal Council and former negotiator of the Gwich'in claim; Chief James Ross; Chief Eugene Pascal; Chief Peter Ross, Charlie Furlong, president of the Metis Local of Aklavik and former president of the Gwich'in Tribal Council; Morris Blake, president, Metis Local of Arctic Red River; Ernest Firth, president of the Metis Local, Fort McPherson; Tommy Wright, president, Metis Local, Inuvik.
In closing, I would like to say that we support the passage of Bill C-94. It is what the Gwich'in people want. There is a saying within that community and it reflects the history of the Gwich'in people.
During the celebrations and during the finalization of the comprehensive claim they passed out stickers, posters and sweat shirts, and on them it said something that speaks loudly for these people. All it says, as we have said many times about being Canadian, "Proud to be Canadian", many of those Gwich'in say "Proud to be Gwich'in".

Clause agreed to.

On clause 5-Renewable Resources Board

Madam Chairman, I would like to ask the minister a question concerning the Renewable Resources Board. Who is going to be sitting on that board and how are the members going to be elected or appointed to that board? Also, what are the powers of that board?

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Madam Chairman, the Renewable Resources Board will comprise members chosen half from the governments, principally the federal government, but with the devolution of authority to the Government of the Northwest Territories, the GNWT will have a role, and half from the Gwich'in Nation people.
It will have authority to review the proposals for the harvesting of renewable resources on the Gwich'in territory. It should be remembered that the harvesting of renewable resources will be enabled with the first right of use to be granted to the Gwich'in people within their own territory. The board will adjudicate and consider the larger interests of the surrounding people, and within the context of the laws of Canada and the Government of the Northwest Territories, the implementation of those rights of the Gwich'in people.

Madam Chairman, I wonder if the minister could indicate whether this concept of a renewable board is something that is being considered in relation to the other claims such as those in British Columbia.
As the minister knows very well, one of the more pressing considerations in the B.C. claims is obviously the fishery. There has been a considerable amount of discussion about impact evaluation, particularly independent impact evaluation in relation to the fishery. Certainly, part of that has been dealt with in this most recent negotiating process between the Government of Canada, the Northwest Territories, the Yukon and the Gwich'in.
December 11, 1992

I wonder if the minister could give us some idea how that concept is evolving or devolving toward the settlement of comprehensive claims in B.C.

speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Madam Chairman, the concept of a Renewable Resource Management Board is an element of our approach to negotiations of a land claims settlement with any First Nations group. However, we do not want to pre-empt the latitude which is taken by the parties to the table in seeking a flexible arrangement.
I would not necessarily undertake that in the case of British Columbia land claims we would create an entity to be called a renewable resource board. There will be in the context of British Columbia land claims, provision for a process of negotiating self-government which is provided for in the Gwich'in land claim agreement as a subsequent step but in the context of British Columbia First Nations may be part and parcel on a parallel track with the settlement of the land based issues. It would be premature to anticipate how those arrangements would work.
In the case of the Gwich'in agreement, the provision for a Renewable Resource Management Board is something that will take place immediately, subject to establishing the membership of that board. It will have immediate effect upon the adoption of this legislation and it will deal with all matters of administering wildlife within the settlement area.

Madam Chairman, I wonder if the minister can explain this. Within the 600 square miles, or whatever the area is, within the boundaries of the Yukon territory, will there be representatives from the Yukon government with respect to renewable resources in that area? Or does it even come under the jurisdiction of this renewable resources board?

speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Madam Chairman, we should understand that the 600 square miles was provided in recognition of the fact that part of the traditional territory of the Gwich'in people was in an area known as the Upper Peel River Valley on the eastern side of the watershed.
However, due to an anomaly in the maps, when the boundary was drawn between Yukon and Northwest Territories, that area which was part of their traditional

He said: Madam Speaker, I am very happy to have this opportunity to begin the debate on Bill C-274, which I tabled in the House in 1989.
It is an act to provide for the conversion to civilian uses of technologies and skills used in the nuclear weapons industry. Bill C-274 is to prepare for the ending of contracts for producing or handling nuclear weapons. It encourages the conversion of technologies of nuclear weapons work into the manufacturing of civilian goods. It helps workers who lose their jobs as a result of the change to find new jobs or it provides benefits to those who become jobless.
The bill requires a company with a nuclear weapons contract to set up a committee to help in changing the plant to civilian production and in retraining the workers. The committee will have equal numbers of representatives from the company and the workers and non-voting community members.
The nuclear weapons company must set up a fund to do all this, and must deposit in it 2.5 per cent of its gross revenues each year. The company and the committee are also to seek funds from other sources.
The bill gives the minister discretion to help the committees and the companies carry out this conversion and provides fines for those who contravene this act.
This bill is supported by two recommendations of a report made to Parliament in October 1992 by the Subcommittee on Arms Export of the Standing Committee on External Affairs and International Trade. That report recommended that Canada prohibit the export of components for nuclear weapons, and also that the government should help to establish a Canadian diversification and resource centre.
My colleague, the New Democrat member for Victoria, will further explain these recommendations later in this hour, as he was a member of that committee. However, I would like to present two strong reasons for converting from the making of nuclear weapons to the making of civilian goods.
First, nuclear weapons use up huge amounts of money, labour, scientific training and research. This is a terrible waste. Instead of these bombs and the missiles to deliver

Private Members' Business
them, we should be making such things as mass transit systems for our cities and instruments for detecting and cleaning up pollution, or we could be developing renewable energy resources that our country and the world badly need. With so much poverty in Canada and in the world we cannot afford to squander our best skills and our best materials.
Second, we already have tens of thousands of these mass killing machines stored in many places around the world, and under many governments. They terrify us, and with good reason. They have killed people already, not only in the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki but in other ways since then, more accidentally, and they have been used to threaten people.
If they are used again they might end all human life. Enough. Let us learn to work to get rid of them, not to make more. We cannot rely on the arms manufacturers by themselves to switch from making killing machines to making things useful for life because arms manufacturing is very profitable.
The arms makers' association that used to mount an annual sales blitz in March in Ottawa called ARMX is now advertising the same weapons to the same international buyers under the slick title of Peacekeeping '93.
Most people do not know to what extent Canada is engaged in producing nuclear weapons systems-vehicles, planes, ships or missiles that are designed primarily to carry nuclear weapons.
Canadians do not make a whole nuclear weapon or a whole nuclear weapons system but we do make many parts of them, mainly to sell to the United States or Britain. I have a list published in the Ploughshares Monitor in March 1990 of the companies that have made these parts since 1986. We have made parts for the following systems: the B-10 bomber, the B-52 stratofor-tress bomber, the tomahawk sea-launched cruise missile, the MX (peacekeeper) missile, the midgetman missile, the Trident submarine, the F-lll aircraft, Lynn HAS 2/3 helicopter, Nimrod MR2 aircraft, P-3 Orton aircraft, P-7A aircraft, S-3 Viking aircraft, SH-60 Seahawk helicopter and Tornado aircraft.
We make them in Waterloo, Ottawa, Rexdale, London, Kitchener, Montreal, Mississauga, Fort Erie, Haley,
Carleton Place, Scarborough, Oakville, Cambridge, Stratford, Winnipeg, Ajax and Peterborough.
The companies that made them are Fusion Penn Inc., Canadian Commercial Corporation, Garrett Canada, Litton Systems Canada, General Motors of Canada, A.T.C. Automation Tooling, Canadian Marconi Company, MIL Vickers, Vadoko International, Cercast Inc., Fleet Industries, General Electric Canada, Haley Industries Ltd., Leigh Instruments Ltd., McDonnell Douglas Canada Ltd., Magna Electronics Corporation, Vac-Aero International, Via-U-Ray Testing, Bristol Aerospace, Menesco Aerospace, West Heights Manufacturing, C.A.E. Electronics, Computing Devices, Canadair Ltd., Dowty Canada, Dowty Electronics Ltd., Unisys Canada, Spar Aerospace Ltd., Leigh Instruments and Walbar of Canada Inc.
The people who made these instruments for nuclear warfare are not bad people. They are good people who are trying to do as we all try to do, put bread on the table. These companies are engaged in legal work. Many of them are subsidized by a government program that uses $500 million per year.
The purpose of this bill is not to blame them but to declare that the people of Canada wish us now to follow a different course of action. We wish to convert war industries to peace industries so that workers like these can put bread on the table doing work that helps people live rather than work that helps people die. I ask members of this House to support this bill.
Since I will be leaving half of my time for other colleagues to give their support to this bill, I wish to close simply with a verse written 25 centuries ago by the prophet Isaiah:
The work of justice shall be peace And the effect of justice quietness and confidence forever Keep judgement and do justice For my salvation is to come and my justice be revealed.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to speak on Bill C-274.

I would like to make a few points. First of all, for the member opposite, there are no nuclear weapons in Canada. We do not have a nuclear weapons industry in Canada.
Second, Canada is committed to the peaceful use of nuclear technology.
Third, the nuclear industry is very important to Canada and nuclear technology plays a very vital role in power generation and in the medical and food industries.
I want to reiterate that Canada does not have a nuclear weapons industry. We removed all our nuclear weapons many years ago and we maintain a defensive policy today that does not include nuclear weapons. However, Canada is recognized internationally for its peacekeeping activities, for its stringent nuclear nonproliferation policy and its full-scope nuclear safeguards, for its arms control and disarmament activities and for its commitment to the elimination of weapons of mass destruction. There is no nuclear weapons industry in Canada.
It is interesting to note that among the six nations of the world that have complete scientific and industrial military capability to support nuclear weapons-Canada, the U.S., United Kingdom, France, Russia and China- Canada is the only one that chooses to apply its nuclear knowledge solely for peaceful purposes, not for the production of nuclear weapons.
Canada's nuclear technology has from its very inception been under civil control. Scientists, physicists and engineers from the National Research Council established Chalk River, the birth place of Canada's nuclear technology, during the Second World War.
The Atomic Energy Control Board was established by an act of Parliament in 1946. Under civilian control AECB is responsible for ensuring that the use of nuclear technology does not pose undue risk to health, safety, security or the environment. Atomic Energy of Canada was formed as a Crown corporation in 1952 and it too is committed to the peaceful development of Canada's unique nuclear option, the Candu reactor, and to the achievement of excellence in related science and technology for the benefit not just of the present but of future Canadians.
In addition to its international obligations under the treaty on non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, Canada
Private Members' Business
has it own stringent nuclear non-proliferation policy and full scope safeguards.
Canada's nuclear industry contributes to quality employment for many sectors of the economy, including the mining of uranium in Saskatchewan, the production of reactor fuel in Ontario, the manufacturing of equipment, the construction and operation of electrical power plants and the production of medical equipment and radio isotopes for use in medicine, cancer treatment and food processing.
Over 30,000 people are employed directly in over 100 companies. They include scientists, engineers, miners, technicians and support staff. The industry provides over
70,000	indirect jobs as well in related supplies and services.
It is also noteworthy that many aboriginal people are employed in the mining of uranium in northern Saskatchewan. Recently, Chief Harry Cook of the La Ronge Indian Band was appointed to the Cameco board of directors.
The nuclear industry in Canada contributes over $4.5 billion to Canada's economy annually, primarily to Ontario and Quebec, but to Saskatchewan, Manitoba, New Brunswick and British Columbia as well. Ontario, for example, has already saved over $17 billion in foreign exchange by using uranium rather than coal for its power.
Nuclear technology is important to our exports. Prospects and orders on hand for Canadian exports of nuclear technology are considerable. They include over $1 billion of Candu technology, annual exports of $1 billion worth of uranium, heavy water supplies estimated at $.5 billion and related engineered products such as radio isotopes, cancer treatment equipment, food irradiators, training simulators and engineering services valued at $250 million.
I would like to quote Mr. David R. Anderson, the vice-president and manager of Canatom Inc., Ontario operations and chairman and CEO of the Canadian Nuclear Association. On the subject of our Candu exports to Korea, he said:
For the Candu unit ordered in 1990 for the Wolsong nuclear power plant, AECL, the prime contractor to Korea Electric Power Corporation, will generate approximately 500 engineering quotation requests to be sent out from the Mississauga offices of AECL-CANDU to selected suppliers in Canadian industry for the components of the Nuclear Steam Supply System.

There are virtually no importations of nuclear equipment into Canada, however. Candu technology is developed, researched, engineered and manufactured right here in Canada. Canada has a positive balance of trade as well in two high technology sectors, aerospace and nuclear reactors, and Canada is not dependent on any country for the supply of key technologies, equipment, services or uranium supplies for its nuclear industry.
The September 1992 report in Business Magazine ranked Canada's top 100 research and development spenders. Atomic Energy of Canada Limited ranked second with 1991 expenditures of $293 million, a 13.2 per cent increase over 1990.
Uranium, I would submit, is a clean source of energy. Nuclear power plants do not produce greenhouse gases. France, for example, generates 75 per cent of its electricity from nuclear reactors and has one of the lowest carbon dioxide emission levels per capita.
Canada, fortunately, is in the forefront of nuclear technology and nowhere is this more evident than in nuclear medicine and radiotherapy. Nuclear medicine provides a reliable and non-intrusive way to diagnose and treat various diseases.
For example, Nordion International Inc., a Canadian company with over 500 employees and annual sales of
over $100 million, is a leading international producer, marketer and supplier of radioisotopes for nuclear medicine and research laboratories. Nordion is best known as the world's largest supplier of cobalt-60, a radioisotope used for sterilization of surgical instruments and cancer therapy.
Nordion also manufactures radiation processing equipment and supplies approximately 85 per cent of the world's requirements for molybdenum 99, moly-99, an essential radioisotope used in many medical procedures.
Theratronics International Limited is another Canadian nuclear technology company with 200 people and annual sales, mostly exports, of over $40 million. Theratronics is a pioneer in the field of radiation therapy and developed the world's first cobalt-60 cancer treatment machine in 1951. Since then the company has installed over 1,800 units in 70 countries. Over a million cancer patients a year are treated using Theratronics' products.
Canada's nuclear medicine community is highly regarded world-wide. Each year vast quantities of the world's food production are spoiled due to food borne bacteria, insect infestations and parasites. Food irradiation solves the problem.
I will not go into details, but I will say that it is because of nuclear technology that people have clean, safe food to eat.
Let me just summarize very briefly. Canada does not have a nuclear weapons industry. Canada has maintained the steadfast commitment to the peaceful use of nuclear technology and the Canadian nuclear industry is making a remarkable contribution to Canada's economy in terms of quality employment, significant export performance, providing a clean, efficient reliable source of energy, providing for our energy security and the development of human, intellectual and natural resources.

First, all Canadian governments since that of Lester Pearson in the 1960s have been in support of non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. Regardless of political party, all governments have agreed on this point and have actually sought ways to strengthen the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Second, in looking at the bill of the hon. member for Trinity-Spadina, one reads that Canada should convert to civilian uses technologies and skills that are used in the manufacture of nuclear weapons.
Under Canada's policy of non-proliferation, Canada does not export uranium to the United States because that country has a nuclear weapons program. Canada does not have a nuclear weapons program and we have never had one. However, we sell steel to the United States. We sell plastics to the United States and several other non-nuclear materials to the United States and these materials could be used in the manufacture of nuclear weapons with no relationship whatsoever to the actual terminology of nuclear.

They are certainly using it in the manufacture of cars, for example, the steel industry.
As a supporter of the non-proliferation treaty, Canada supports the right of developing countries to develop nuclear technology for peaceful means only. Many poorer countries are interested in nuclear energy because huge amounts of energy can be supplied. You cannot improve the way of life of people unless they

have an energy source to modernize their production in their every day life, even the decencies of electric lights and fridges for the saving of food.
Canadian policy is that Canada will not give nuclear technology to a country unless that country agrees to International safeguards by the International Atomic Energy Agency. It is interesting to note that the Candu reactor is the most useless of reactors for those countries wanting to use the uranium in missile warheads. Heavy water is used as a coolant in the Candu reactor. This means that it uses natural uranium. As such, there is no need for a reprocessing facility in the Candu reactor system. The proportion of fissionable uranium, U-235, that is produced from the Candu is only 0.7 per cent.
If a country wanted to acquire a nuclear energy facility with the underlying intention of obtaining weapons-grade uranium for warheads, it would need a reprocessing facility to make this kind of uranium.
As indicated, the Candu is useless in this regard as it does not come equipped with a reprocessing facility and that is one of the safeguards of the Canadian Candu reactor. Canada is a major supporter of the non-proliferation treaty and has been since day one as one of the founders of it.
Of all the countries in the world, Canada is the leader in the promoting of the non-proliferation treaty dealing with nuclear weapons. There are only six that independently have the nuclear technology to develop nuclear weapons programs. These are the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Russia, the Peoples' Republic of China and Canada.
Other countries suspected of having nuclear weapons got the technology from other sources and did not develop it domestically.
Of the six countries I listed that have innovative nuclear technology, Canada is the only one with the capability to develop nuclear weapons but did not do so. We have never done so. This certainly says something about the kind of people Canadians are.
From the days of Lester B. Pearson it has been a policy of Canada not to develop an independent nuclear weapons system. Every government to date has stuck with that.

Canada has a nuclear program dedicated to peaceful purposes only. It has developed the Candu nuclear power reactor, a wide variety of medical and industrial radiochemical products, and a uranium industry that is the largest exporter in the world.
I just wish we could see the day when the critics of Canada's peaceful nuclear industry would begin to realize and talk about the tremendous strides that have been made in medicine in the nuclear field. Chalk River is a perfect example of what has been done in the field of medicine.
To ensure that these industries are not jeopardized by links to nuclear weapons, great care has been taken to develop international agreements with our trading partners. The important segments of Canada's nuclear non-proliferation policy are the bilateral agreements signed with all trading partners and the nuclear weapons non-proliferation treaty, which I have mentioned.
That is administered by the International Atomic Energy Agency. We have about 20 people working at the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.
From the very beginning of international trade in nuclear products and technologies, Canada has required assurances from trading partners that Canadian-supplied items would not be used in any nuclear weapons programs. This policy has been strengthened, starting in 1974, requiring all trading partners to make the following basic commitments in bilateral nuclear co-operation agreements:
Canadian-supplied items will not be associated with nuclear explosive devices.
A provision for fall-back safeguards must be made if the International Atomic Energy Agency is unable to continue with its inspections and safeguard functions.
No transfer of Canadian-supplied items can be made without prior consent by Canada. They cannot be transferred from one country to another without Canadian consent. It is part of the agreement.
Enrichment of Canadian-supplied uranium beyond 20 per cent is prohibited; and adequate physical protection will be applied to ensure compliance with the previous conditions.
I see you are giving me the high sign, Mr. Speaker. I just want to say that Canada has been one of the leaders
in the nuclear industry for peaceful purposes. Yes, we have a lot of expertise and good technology in this field, but it should be supported by the public at large for the good work that it has done in medicine and in biology and many other fields.
It is a great science. I do not know why we are debating this bill today because it really does not apply to Canada.

I thought, Mr. Speaker, you said the hon. member for Christmas. I know that he is a very avuncular fellow. I do appreciate your recognizing me and the opportunity to participate in this debate.
I am sure that the thousands, if not millions, of people across this country who believe very strongly, now that the cold war is over, in a peace dividend will be very disappointed that the speaker for the Liberal Party when speaking on this bill not only completely misconceived it but essentially spoke against it.
It is very revealing that the only person the Liberal Party puts up is someone who would go on about the Candu reactor which has absolutely nothing to do with the resolution before this House.
This resolution calls for conversion from a nuclear military weapons industry, not civilian industry, but nuclear military industry. It is a very critical and important issue to millions of people across this country.
We are not surprised that the member for Winnipeg South would oppose this resolution, although she too also misconceived the point of the resolution.
I want to congratulate the member for Trinity-Spadi-na who has pursued this issue diligently for many years and has finally seen this bill come before the House. It is a great tribute to him.
He has served this House very well. He has indicated he will not be running in the next election and this House will miss him. He has been a conscience of the House on this and many other issues. I want to assure him that if I and others are back, we will carry on the fight for the important concept he has embodied in this resolution.
Under the rules of the House, if we cannot get agreement and the matter dies on the Order Paper, I would ask all members to agree that this be referred to the Standing Committee on National Defence and Veterans Affairs for consideration.

This bill calls for conversion of the nuclear weapons industry in Canada. It should not be misunderstood. This country is completely committed to the manufacture of components of nuclear weapons systems and the export of those components particularly to the United States of America. This bill by establishing the national policy of conversion is a very important bill for our country to accept.
I want to use the few minutes I have to draw the attention of House and of the country to an important companion study done by the Standing Committee on External Affairs and International Trade.
Last year and leading into early this year, a sub-committee on arms exports undertook a very comprehensive study of the future of Canadian military goods production and export. In the course of that study, it made a series of important recommendations, two of which bear directly on this resolution.
The first is recommendation 12. It recommends that an export control list be established which would include the components of nuclear weapons. This recommendation was unanimously accepted by the committee and recommended to this House by the members, including representatives from the government side and from the Liberal side. Where are they today? Why are they not standing up in support of this bill which would embody at least in part that unanimous recommendation?
The committee also recommended a number of other steps which would be in the spirit of this bill. It recommended that the government act upon the 1982 request of the United Nations General Assembly to prepare a national assessment of the relationship between disarmament and development in Canada.
The committee recommended that the Canadian defence procurement policy be changed to foster a leading edge in innovative industrial capability in civilian as well as military high technology products in areas of surveillance and monitoring, verification, sovereignty protection and peacekeeping.
The committee also recommended that the mandate of the Defence Industry Production Program be changed to encourage conversion and diversification and that it
Private Members' Business
primarily focus on technologies with significant civilian spin-off potential.
It also called on DIPP funds to be available to assist when a defence industry had been closed. I want to conclude with drawing the attention of the House to this most important recommendation which is at the heart of this important bill brought before the House by the member for Trinity-Spadina.
I will read recommendation 20 it in its entirety.
The Committee recommends that the government support the establishment of a Canadian Diversification and Conversion Resource Centre. The Centre should gather and disseminate data on diversification and conversion efforts in Canada and overseas, on federal, provincial and municipal programs which might assist diversification and conversion efforts, and on new products and markets. The Centre should also monitor Canadian and international defence production, defence industry support and military goods export control policies, and encourage the establishment of conversion committees.
This bill calls upon the nuclear weapons industry to establish conversion committees and the recommendation would broaden that to cover all military production in this country.
I commend this bill to the House and urge all members to support it.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak to the bill introduced by my colleague from Spadina.
The bill is to provide for the conversion to civilian uses of technologies and skills used in the nuclear weapons industry. In prefacing my remarks, I should point out that my own constituency, particularly the community of Trail, produced the heavy water for the Manhattan project. The Cominco Special Metals and Electronics Division produced a lot of the sophisticated technology used in President Reagan's ill-fated Star Wars program.
Therefore, to say that we have never had an industry in Canada that has contributed to the nuclear weapons industry and delivery system is quite wrong.
The main purpose of my remarks is to point out, in supporting the principle of this bill, that there are opportunities that I and many others feel are being missed for Canada to get aboard, gear up for and contribute in a major way to what should be and will be a major nuclear clean-up industry on a world-wide scale.

Private Members' Business
The delegation of my colleagues and I, headed by my friend, the member for Okanagan-Shuswap and three other New Democratic members were the first Canadian parliamentary delegation to visit the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State at Richland, Washington last March to investigate what is going on at that facility. It is a major clean-up.
I will read very briefly what they are doing to clean up the mess left over from the Manhattan project, the number of plutonium development facilities and about nine reactors that used to exist on that site. It is setting the pace and is a laboratory for the world in terms of the nuclear clean-up industry. I just want to point out what is happening in the local area. I will quote from The Economist of August 15, 1992:
Doing something about this problem is revitalising the local economy. More than 16,000 technicians, engineers and scientists are now beavering away on the site. During the past year the population of Richland grew by 10%. Home prices have risen 30% in three years-unusual in an environmental disaster-area. As Ralph DeSibio of Westinghouse Hanford, an erstwhile plutonium producer and now the prime contractor for the clean-up, puts it, "We're sitting on a waste mine."
It may be a waste mine but it is a gold mine for many of the people there. It can be a major contributor to more and sophisticated jobs in Canada, if we accept our responsibilities to help lead the way.
The federal government should be co-ordinating and communicating with American Westinghouse officials and attempting to get a piece of the action or at least be in an observer capacity at that site in Washington. In that way, we would be in a better position to clean up our own matters, whether they stem from military nuclear hardware or the clean-up of civilian nuclear problems. That is another major problem that we have not dealt with either. It would also allow us to contribute, in a more meaningful way, and we should be beginning to do that as well, in the major problems in the nuclear industry in what used to be the Soviet Union.
For a number of reasons, including demand reasons and the state of public opinion, the nuclear industry in Canada, and I am mainly talking about the peaceful nuclear industry, is gearing down in many ways. We can create employment, create technology, be on the leading edge in the so-called global marketplace that the government likes to talk to us about, if we are in a position to understand the clean-up technologies that are taking place. We could lend a helping hand to what otherwise
will be a major disaster for the whole world and help to clean up some of the problems left over by the change of regimes and the inappropriate and old fashioned nuclear technology that existed in the Soviet Union.
That is a disaster waiting to happen. We have potential disasters from the peacetime nuclear industry in Canada unless we are in a position to get on board and help to clean up this major waste disposal problem on a worldwide basis. There are opportunities there, let us grab them.
The intent of the bill before us is to begin to move us in that direction and I hope the government does.

Mr. Speaker, I just learned that the hon. member for Trinity-Spa-dina will not run in the next election, and since I may not have the opportunity to do so later on, I should like to congratulate him for his hard work on behalf of his constituents.
Canadians can be proud of their country's record on arms control and nuclear non-proliferation. Traditionally, these issues have been among the priorities of Canadian foreign policy since the Second World War.
In the late 1940s Canada rejected the development of nuclear weapons. Instead, Canadian efforts in this area have targeted the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. Electrical power generation, medical applications of radioisotopes, are among the contributions that Canadian nuclear science has made to human betterment. A corollary of this policy of focusing on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy was the decision to pursue in a consequent and unremitting manner initiatives towards nuclear arms control and non-proliferation. Canada has always stood on the side of peace and opposed war.
Canada was among the first nations to ratify the non-proliferation treaty in 1969. The treaty continues as the essential cornerstone of the global non-proliferation system. Canada's unwavering support for the NPT rests on its indispensable character in stemming the spread of nuclear weapons. At the same time, the NPT also permits the dissemination of the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. Canada, through the International Atomic Energy Agency and other channels, has played a strong role in this area.

The essential character of the NPT has prompted Canada to promote actively universal adoption of the treaty. Such a stance supports Canada's ultimate objective: the total elimination of nuclear weapons.
Canada has always been in the forefront of multilateral efforts to reduce conventional weapons, stem nuclear proliferation, and otherwise work for peace. The end of the cold war greatly reduced the threat of nuclear war, but this most welcome development also brought to the fore new and pressing challenges.
For that reason, the Prime Minister, in a seminal speech last year at Johns Hopkins University, set out an agenda for action on non-proliferation.
First, the NPT must be strengthened by its indefinite extension and by universal accession to it. These objectives were reflected in the political declaration issued by summit leaders meeting in Munich last year. Since then, Canada has participated in multilateral and bilateral initiatives to urge acceptance of the NPT. These efforts have met with considerable success and, to date, 155 countries have acceded to the NPT.
Nonetheless, a number of key countries remain outside the treaty. Further efforts are needed to persuade states like India, Pakistan, Algeria, Israel, Chile, Argentina, and Brazil. This is particularly important as we move to prepare for the NPT Extension Conference in 1995.
Second, nuclear cheating must be stopped by strengthening the mandate of the International Atomic Energy Agency and increasing its resources. Canada will support giving the IAEA the teeth-the authority and the resources-to inspect any time anywhere. To this end, a Canadian expert is participating in a high-level group to develop strengthened and streamlined safeguards.
Third, controls on the export of nuclear technologies, materials and equipment must be tightened. With strong pressure from Canada and others the Nuclear Suppliers Group has agreed to require the acceptance of full-scope safeguards by recipient countries as a condition of supply.
Private Members' Business
Fourth, the migration of nuclear brainpower must be stopped. To that end, Canada has contributed generously to the establishment of International Science and Technology Centres in Kiev and Moscow so that scientists of Russia and Ukraine apply their knowledge and expertise to peaceful endeavours and not add to the world's stock of nuclear weapons and delivery systems.
Fifth, security co-operation must be strengthened regionally to reduce underlying causes of tensions, particularly in such chronic hot spots as the Korean Peninsula, the Middle East and the sub-continent. Canada is bringing its experience and expertise in verification to the arms control working group of the Middle East peace talks and we have been instrumental in encouraging the countries of the north Pacific to consider ways to enhance their security through cooperation and dialogue.

He said: Mr. Speaker, I would like to start by taking a few moments to thank hon. members for their unanimous consent, considering the fact that we had to extend our sitting hours today in order to pass this legislation. I am pleased to say that the bill before the House today, now at third reading, has met with a very broad consensus. The bill itself and the proposed amendments were given thorough consideration by a legislative committee. There was also a detailed study by various environmental groups. This legislation is the culmination of many years' work, as a result of which we were able to table this bill in the House.

Government Orders

An act respecting the protection of certain species of animals and plants was presented for second reading on March 17 and reported back by the legislative committee on June 18.
There are some changes proposed to the bill and I am happy to report that the changes, as far as I know, are the object of a wide consensus on behalf of all members of this House. There has been a very inclusive process of study of this bill in the legislative committee.
May I also add that the parliamentary secretary for the Department of the Environment, the member for Brandon-Souris, played a key role, as he did on other pieces of legislation, in facilitating the work before the legislative committee on this matter. I thank him today on the record, given the fact that as usual he will have done most of the work in the parliamentary process in advancing this bill.
This bill is about the important stress that is now on the world's wildlife populations. We know there is considerable stress on our ecosystems, on the species themselves, and within the species in certain cases. In the case of Canada this is especially significant given the richness of our geography and the fact that we have very key species that are threatened and measures are required to protect them.
The act is new federal legislation. It will protect wild animals and plants by regulating international and interprovincial trade in them and their parts and products.
There are three objectives: first, to help protect wild animal and plant species in foreign countries from poaching and smuggling; second, to protect Canada's wild animal and plant species from illegal trade; and, third, to protect Canada's ecosystems from the introduction of designated harmful species or so-called biological pollutants. It will replace the 1941 Game Export Act and regulations first made in 1975 under the Export and Import Permits Act through which the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species is implemented in Canada, otherwise known as CITES.
As mentioned a few seconds ago, this piece of legislation has gone under some very thorough and very extensive debate within committee itself and some
amendments address the concerns that were expressed in the committee.
For example, this new act will allow Canada to support the efforts of other countries to conserve and protect species, especially endangered ones. It will also prohibit wild animals and plants from being brought into Canada if they have been obtained or otherwise dealt with in violation of foreign conservation laws.
There is a very legitimate trade in certain species or threatened wild animals or plants going on now. That being the case, I should point out that this bill is something that will not impede that trade but will rather create a context in which it can happen with the safeguards we are all seeking.

Mr. Speaker, as you know, we are conducting a debate on this bill, an act respecting the protection of certain species of wild animals and plants.
We welcome on our side of the House the return of this bill roughly 13 months after it was introduced the first time.
We think that this legislation is long overdue. We want to report that a considerable amount of work was done in committee with a very strong and vigorous input on the part of the member for Skeena, who I am sure is very anxious to speak in a few moments on the strength of the bill, both in terms of international and interprovincial trade of endangered species.
In essence, the purpose of the bill is to protect certain species of animals and plants when it comes to international and interprovincial trade. The prohibition, and this is important for the Canadian travelling public, is to the effect that a person should not import into Canada any animals or plants in contravention of any law of any foreign state, meaning any law that is endorsed and subscribed to in connection with foreign trade by nations which adhere to the convention on international trade in endangered species.
This bill brings Canada in line with other international accords such as the convention on biodiversity and especially with the convention on international trade in endangered species.
It intends to protect biological diversity globally. It intends to band illegal trade of endangered species, fauna and flora.
Last year a convention on international trade in endangered species was strengthened and a list of protected species was extended to include over 1,000 species.
These international actions are no reason for complacency. The House may have heard about research reports that through poaching, the African rhino is on the verge of extinction in southern Africa. The African elephant is still in a precarious state because of the slaughter for the purpose of providing tusks and profit making.
A report issued only this week by the United Nations Environment Program warns that between 100 and 300 species a day, flora and fauna combined, become extinct through habitat destruction, especially through the destruction of tropical rainforests, coral reefs, wetlands and other biologically diverse and rich ecosystems.
Therefore, extinction is not someone else's problem. In the remote areas in Canada, for instance, there are at least 25 endangered species.
My next point is that while we support the passage of this bill because it is important, we would like it to go further. We would like to have fines increased to ensure that they are in line with other international penalties for illegal trade, and possibly the member for Skeena will address this subject more effectively based on his wide-ranging experience.
The fines as far as we are concerned could be brought to $100,000 for individuals and it would not be too little. The fines and criminal charges must be strict enough to ensure that Canada does not become a haven for smugglers.
Aside from the offences, this bill is about international trade, and yet we need parallel legislation which takes an ecosystem management and conservation approach to the protection of species. That is what some of us have proposed by way of private members' bills, including a private members' bill by the member for Davenport, Bill C-209, which I would like to bring to the attention of the minister in the House. I am sure that he already knows about it. This bill intends to provide protection for Canada's own biological diversity. It is intended to identify, protect, if you like rehabilitate, flora and fauna threatened or endangered by human activities in our nation.
Finally, once this bill is given third reading, we on this side of the House urge the government to move swiftly with its promulgation and to make good on the government's commitment contained in the green plan to increase public awareness through environmental education, environmental communications, the schools, through all means that are available. We will build on the urgent need to strengthen wildlife protection for the enrichment and enjoyment of present and, first and foremost because of the pressures to which the minister himself alluded earlier, for future generations.
December 11, 1992

We are glad to give support to this bill and to take this opportunity to urge the minister to also take an initiative for the protection of Canada's own biological diversity. I know that it is close to his heart and that he will move swiftly with the determination which characterizes him, for which he is well known, to fill this gap for which this measure is badly needed.
