speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak in support of Bill C-42, and that good will actually got it to the point of being able to pass today. I was worried earlier today as I sat and the hours went by that perhaps those which we are here speaking on behalf of, which are the wild plants and animals of this planet, might not have any voices speaking on their behalf as this year rings its way out.
This has been a profound act of political will. It is a kind of consultation that I do not think very many pieces of legislation have ever been through. A national-interprovincial-territorial consultation process began in 1982. The legislation itself actually started to formulate back in
1987.	It has been a very long and tedious process to get it to where it is today.
Frankly, it is now a pretty good piece of legislation and the minister should be complimented for having ridden herd as he has and provided the necessary political will to actually get it to the floor of the House. I know, with the legislative agenda that there has been in the last little while, getting a piece of legislation about wild plants and animals to the floor of this Chamber with all of the other competing interests has not been an easy task.
I also think that the minister and those on the government side listened at least with due diligence to the concerns raised from this side about the issues of fines. They were substantially altered. They are considerable. It is in that area to which I direct my remarks for a moment, because I think there is a responsibility not so much now of the Minister of the Environment but of his colleagues in the field of justice and in law enforcement to make sure that law enforcement personnel generally in this country are aware of what this bill is all about.
As my friend from Davenport pointed out, this is more about plants and animal species that are being trafficked internationally and in some cases interprovincially than it is to protect the biological nature of this country. We do not have a lot of endangered species, in fact we have
Government Orders
very few that are listed under CITES. We have 195 endangered species at the moment that are listed by COSEWIC, Canada's committee in this field on endangered plants and animals. There is a great deal of work to be done in that area.
On the education of the enforcement personnel, the minister is committed to $12.3 million under the green plan-I spoke to him earlier today. I am quite confident that the funds are there and are going to be delivered- and for the 29 new person years. I know that excellent public servants such as Mr. McLean in the minister's department will be eagerly anticipating learning later today that the 29 person years will in fact still be delivered by the Minister of the Environment, perhaps over the next five years instead of over the next six, to get it jump-started and going.
So there is that one big job on educating enforcers of the law.
The other much bigger one is to educate the bench. In my own experience, it follows the issue of the exportation of things like bear gall bladders and paws and various "exotic parts" of Canadian wildlife internationally-
Regrettably when offenders are finally caught, charged, and brought before the courts such as some of my own constituents, the sentences are inappropriate. One fellow in particular was before the courts after having been convicted more than 100 times already and came back before the bench and was not given what I consider to be an appropriate sentence.
I am hoping that all members of this House will take some interest in this issue, in particular the Minister of Justice, and those who have some direct access to educational materials for the bench. Make sure that the judges and the courts in this country understand the seriousness with which this bill was taken by the members who worked on it.
The fines are not inconsiderable. They go up into the hundreds of thousands of dollars for corporations that are involved. There are extensive periods of incarceration, and it is certainly something that I as a member of this House, and I know the Minister of the Environment is hoping that these kinds of sentences will be handed down.

December 11, 1992
Government Orders
I know that when a corporate entity appears before a court in any area of this country with an orchid in hand and the lawyer gets up and extols the virtue of the corporation and the client and says: "Oh, my Lord, you are not possibly going to put my client away for six months or a year and fine him or her $300,000 over this one measley orchid?" I hope the bench will come to understand that this legislation, at least in the foreseeable future is going to become more, not less, important.
According to Edward Wilson, the global authority at the moment on the loss of biodiversity, we are losing at least 10 entire species an hour on this planet. It is mind boggling. That is an entire species of parrots, entire species of orchids, entire species of other forms of plants and animals. In Somalia there is not one elephant left. At the turn of the century we were losing maybe a specie a month but the time clock is accelerating so fast that legislation like this has become mandatory.
Even though the fines and degree of incarceration were not brought to the levels that I think were necessary, meaning there is a possibility of Canada continuing to be a conduit for smuggling, and a conduit for poaching, I would hope through stringent and rigid enforcement, there would be zero tolerance for the smuggling of endangered plants and animals at the border.
I do not care what excuses some people have when they have a little snake hidden inside their cowboy boots, that they are taking and saying they did not know it was worth $100,000. I just do not buy it any more.
The amount of money being made, as we heard from witnesses in terms of the traffic in endangered plants and animals is comparable to the drug trade. We are talking hundreds of millions being exchanged for things like bear gall bladders for people who think it is some kind of erotic medicine. It is a very serious state of affairs and I am pleased this bill is being passed.
I know I told the minister and my friend from Davenport I was not going to talk very long, but I can get wound up into these things quite quickly.
We want to pass this, Madam Speaker, and I do have a few other things I need to say.
The minister pointed out the bill does three things. Canadians should not be fooled by the brand name. It is called the Wild Plant and Animal Protection Act. It does not protect those endangered species and biosystems inside Canada. This brings us into compliance with CITES, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. There is about 50,000 species now listed in the appendices of CITES. Most of them are plants like orchids but there are many mammals listed in it and Canada's own COSEWIC listings should be included.
It does protect some of Canada's wild plant and animal species from illegal trade. It protects some Canadian ecosystems from the introduction of designated harmful species and it helps to protect wild animal and plant species in foreign countries from poaching and smuggling. The initiatives of the legislation are good.
As I said earlier, the kind of consultations the Minister of the Environment conducted are first class where there are consultations with the provinces and the territories and we get them all on board.
Now the job is getting the enforcers on board, the 29 professionals who can identify the particular endangered species that are often smuggled in, particularly at our airports but also at our ports and in vehicles coming into Canada. It is a big, big job and the public needs to be educated about the severity of it.
I do hope the minister will soon take the next step. That is to move on the kind of endangered species legislation there is at least in the United States. I would not take it as a specific model, but clearly there needs to be a legislative move in this country to protect endangered spaces and endangered species. I know the minister is committed to doing that.
I will end by saying it is a bill that Canadians should not be tricked by. It does not do a whole lot for plants and animals inside Canada, but it is a very useful weapon in the arsenal of dealing with international crime, even those international petty criminals who think that just smuggling a few orchids is not that bad. There is big money in it and has to be stopped.

I am pleased this is the last debate to take place before Christmas because it is a bill well worthy of singing a few tunes to. I congratulate the Minister of the Environment for getting it through.
Motion agreed to, bill read the third time and passed. [Translation]
